questions.text: 1. A 32-year-old patient presents with headache, nausea, vomiting, and neck stiffness, which rapidly progresses to confusion and hallucinations. CSF sample is collected, which is purulent and shows reduced glucose levels. Motile trophozoites are seen on a wet mount of the CSF. A detailed history reveals a recent visit to a swimming pool. Which of the following is likely an offending organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of acute and fulminant meningitis. The presence of motile trophozoites on saline microscopy with a history of exposure to water from overhead rainwater harvesting tanks suggests an infection by Naegleria fowleri.

Naegleria fowleri is also known as the brain-eating amoeba. It occurs in 3 forms: cyst, amoeboid trophozoite and flagellate trophozoite forms. The amoeboid form is the feeding, growing, and replicating form of the parasite, and is seen on the surface of vegetation, mud, and water. The flagellate form occurs when trophozoites are transferred to distilled water. Cysts are seen in unfavourable environmental conditions such as nutritional deprivation and desiccation.

The infection usually follows swimming in warm freshwater rivers or ponds, or poorly maintained swimming pools or nasal irrigation with contaminated tap water. The amoebae invade the nasal mucosa and pass through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges. The incubation period is 2 days-2 weeks.

It causes an acute suppurative fulminant infection of the CNS known as primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM). Symptoms include fever, headache, vomiting, stiff neck, ataxia, seizure and coma. The disease is rapidly progressive and has a mortality rate of 98%.

CSF is the specimen of choice and should be examined immediately and not refrigerated. CSF is thick and purulent, with pus cells >20,000/μL, elevated protein, and reduced sugar levels (mimics bacterial meningitis). CSF microscopy shows motile amoeboid trophozoites on wet mount.  Brain biopsy demonstrates trophozoites having sky blue cytoplasm with a pink nucleus. CSF samples can be cultivated on non-nutrient agar cultured with bacterial supplements like E. coli.

Naegleria characteristically feeds on bacteria and crawls over the lawn culture to produce the ‘trail sign’.  Although most cases lead to a poor outcome, some sources have reported successful treatment with intravenous amphotericin B. 

The image given below shows various forms of Naegleria fowleri:



The image given below shows the life cycle of Naegleria fowleri:



Other options:

Option A: Toxoplasma gondii is transmitted through contaminated meat, feco-oral transmission through house pets like cats, or the birth canal. Infection leading to encephalitis usually occurs in immunocompromised hosts, where the clinical manifestations in immunocompetent hosts are self-limited.

Option C: Acanthamoeba causes granulomatous amoebic encephalitis (GAE), which is more insidious in onset and has a longer incubation period. Acanthameoba is non-motile. It is also known to cause Acanthamoeba keratitis in users of contact lenses. It exists as an active trophozoite form and a resistant cystic form. The trophozoite is large, 20- 50 µmin size and characterised by spine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia). It differs from Naegleria in not having a flagellate stage and in forming cysts in tissues that are polygonal and double-walled. 

Option D: Balamuthia is a leptomixid free-living amoeba. It causes GAE in both healthy and immunocompromised individuals. It only has the ameboid trophozoite stage; the flagellate stage is absent. Infection is acquired via the respiratory tract, skin lesions, or eyes. The life cycle resembles that of Acanthamoeba. Diagnosis is made by identifying trophozoites in CSF.

questions.text: 2. A middle-aged farmer sustained a puncture wound on his foot while working in his farmland. A few days later, he started experiencing intense pain and stiffness in his jaw associated with difficulty swallowing. The toxin responsible for the condition described uses which of the following modes of transport?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes tetanus, and the toxin responsible is tetanus toxin, which uses retrograde axonal transport. 

Neurotoxins like tetanus toxin act by preventing the release of neurotransmitters at the neuromuscular junction (NMJ). It binds irreversibly to the presynaptic membrane of the NMJ and travels to the motor neuron cell body in the spinal cord via retrograde axonal transport (200mm/day). It is then picked up by the terminals of the presynaptic inhibitory interneurons, wherein it attaches to the gangliosides and blocks the release of glycine and GABA. This further enhances the activity of the motor neurons. Symptoms of tetanus include trismus (lock jaw), dysphagia, and excessive drooling of saliva. 

Other options: 

Option A and B & D. Orthograde transport moves substances from the cell body to the axon terminals along microtubules. It uses two molecular motors, dynein and kinesin. This transport has a fast axonal component (around 400 mm/day) and a slow axonal component (0.5–10 mm/day).

questions.text: 3. The shaded region in the given diagram indicates:
questions.solution:
The shaded region indicates the area of accepting a null hypothesis. 

The given diagram is a normal distribution curve. The shaded region indicates the area where we fail to reject the null hypothesis. In the given normal distribution curve, this corresponds to Mean ± 2 Standard Deviations (SD).

This interval covers about 95% of the distribution, which is the confidence interval. Any sample value falling within this range results in a p-value greater than 0.05, meaning there is not enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis. Hence, this is the acceptance region for the null hypothesis.

By convention, if the probability value is less than or equal to 0.05 (5%), most researchers say that an outcome is statistically significant.

* If a test statistic falls inside the shaded middle 95% region, we say the result is not statistically significant → fail to reject the null hypothesis, i.e. accept the null hypothesis

* If it falls in either of the two extreme ends of the normal distribution (outside ±1.96 SD), the result is statistically significant → reject null hypothesis

Pearl PM1098: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

* A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.

* It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.

* If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.

* It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

* The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.

* In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.

* A null hypothesis is represented by H0.

* If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

* If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.

* This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.

* When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.

* By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.

* If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.

* Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

* The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.

* It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.

* From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.

* This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.

* It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.

* The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.

* Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

* The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.

* It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.

* If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.

* The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

* The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.

* It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.

* By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.

* Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.

* A test's power will increase in the following conditions:

* If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.

* If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.

* If sampling error decreases.

* If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: 4. The occurrence of recurrent and regular contraction of a muscle that is subjected to a quick and sustained stretch, accurately defines which of the following?
questions.solution:
Clonus is defined as the occurrence of recurrent/repetitive and regular contraction of a muscle that is subjected to a quick and sustained stretch.

Clonus is seen in states with high gamma motor neuron activity. It is a rhythmic oscillatory series of muscle contractions that is induced by stretching the tendon. It can be elicited in many joints but is most commonly seen in the ankle joint by suddenly dorsiflexing the foot and maintaining light upward pressure. It is seen in UMN lesions and is associated with other signs of UMN lesions like spasticity. A sustained clonus of five or more beats is considered abnormal.

The management of clonus frequently revolves around addressing its underlying aetiology. In certain cases, the implementation of physical therapy with stretching exercises has been observed to mitigate occurrences of clonus.

Immunosuppressive agents such as azathioprine and corticosteroids, anticonvulsants including primidone, levetiracetam and clonazepam, have demonstrated efficacy in the therapeutic management of clonus. Botulinum toxin has been employed as a means to inhibit the release of acetylcholine in the muscle, hence impeding the occurrence of rhythmic muscular contractions commonly associated with clonus.

Other options 

Option A: Athetosis is characterised by writhing and sinuous movements, particularly noticeable in the digits and extremities and is seen in patients with hepatic encephalopathy.

Option B: Tremor can be defined as involuntary motions with no intent caused by alternating contractions of opposing/antagonistic muscle groups. 

Option D: Asterixis is defined as an intermittency of maintained posture in patients with hepatic encephalopathy, gravity and the inherent elasticity of muscles produce the movement which the patient attempts to correct but then overshoots leading to this movement disorder.

questions.text: 5. Which of the following parts of the bone in the image forms a boundary of the facial recess of the ear?
questions.solution:
The bony part marked as 3 is the short process of the incus, which is attached to the fossa incudis, which forms the superior boundary of the facial recess. 

The facial recess/posterior sinus/suprapyramidal recess is a depression found in the posterior wall, lateral to the pyramid. Clinical significance of the facial recess is that it provides direct access to middle ear pathology without disturbing the posterior canal wall (intact canal wall technique)

Boundaries of the facial recess are: 

* Medially: Vertical part of the facial nerve

* Laterally: Chorda tympani

* Superiorly: Fossa incudis (attached to short process of incus)



The incus has a body and a short process, both of which lie in the attic, and a long process which attaches to the stapes and lies vertically. The short process of the incus in the attic is attached to the fossa incudis, forming a superior boundary of the facial recess.

The malleus consists of 5 parts, which include, head, neck, handle, a lateral and an anterior process. The lateral process forms a knob-like projection on the outer surface of the tympanic membrane and gives attachment to the anterior and posterior malleolar folds.

The stapes bone comprises five parts: a head, neck, anterior crus, posterior crus, and footplate. The footplate is connected to the oval window by the annular ligament.

All three ear ossicles are responsible for conducting sound energy from the tympanic membrane to the oval window and further to the inner ear fluid.

questions.text: 6. The most common manifestation that you would expect in a child infected by E. histolytica is:
questions.solution:
The most common manifestation of Entamoeba histolytica infection in children is asymptomatic cyst passage.

Amebiasis:

* Caused by Entamoeba histolytica

* Trophozoites are responsible for tissue invasion and destruction.

Clinical manifestations:

* Asymptomatic cyst passer (carrier): Infected individuals harbor the parasite in the intestinal lumen without tissue invasion. They pass cysts in stool, which act as a major reservoir for transmission.

* Amebic Colitis

* Colicky abdominal pains and frequent bowel movements (6–8/day).

* Diarrhea associated with tenesmus, heme-positive stool. (Option B)

* Some may have only intermittent diarrhea alternating with constipation. (Option D)

* Trophozoites invade the intestinal mucosa, produce flask-shaped ulcers. 

* Amebic Liver Abscess (Option A)

* It occurs in <1% of infected individuals.

* Fever is the hallmark of amebic liver abscess.

* It is associated with abdominal pain, abdominal distention, and enlargement and tenderness of the liver.

* Changes at the base of the right lung, such as elevation of the diaphragm and atelectasis or effusion, may also occur.

* The most common finding is a single abscess in the right hepatic lobe, detected on ultrasonography, computed tomography, or magnetic resonance imaging.

questions.text: 7. A 40-year-old man who was non-compliant with his tuberculosis medication now comes with back pain. You suspect the disease has disseminated to the spine. Which part in the given image of the spine, is most commonly affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the patient is likely to have developed tuberculosis of the spine. The most common pattern of involvement in Pott's spine/ TB spine is the paradiscal type.

The structures marked in the image:

* Posterior spinal elements

* Paradiscal area of the vertebra

* Anterior vertebral body

* Central vertebral body

TB spine occurs secondary to a pulmonary or gastrointestinal primary and spreads through the Batson's plexus of veins (paravertebral plexus). It most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region. 

Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

* Paradiscal - contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae and the middle intervening disc are affected. This is due to the high oxygen requirements of tubercular bacteria and the corresponding high blood supply in this region by the segmental vessels.

* Central - the body of the vertebra is involved leading to collapse (causing wedging or concertina) of the affected vertebra. This leads to spinal deformities such as kyphosis and gibbous.

* Anterior - the anterior part of body is affected and spreads through the anterior longitudinal ligament.

* Posterior - the posterior complex (pedicle, lamina, spinous process, and transverse process) is affected.

Image showing various parts and patterns of involvement in Pott's spine.

questions.text:
8. A young boy who underwent an ileal resection developed bilateral centrocecal scotomas. Which of the following enzymes are dependent on the vitamin that is deficient in this condition?

1. Methylmalonyl CoA mutase 2. Cystathionine synthase 3. Folate reductase 4. Methionine synthase
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of bilateral centrocecal scotomas in a patient who had an ileal resection is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase and methionine synthase (1 and 4) are vitamin B12–dependent enzymes.

The terminal ileum absorbs vitamin B12. Thus, after ileal resection as in this patient, the development of vitamin B12 deficiency is likely. The patient’s bilateral centrocecal scotomas are a neurological manifestation of B12 deficiency due to optic nerve demyelination.

The vitamin B12–dependent enzymes:

* Methionine synthase (homocysteine methyltransferase): It catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine.

* Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase: It catalyzes the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. The activity of this enzyme is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonyl-CoA and urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid, which is used to assess vitamin B12 nutritional status.

Urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid is also used to differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency.

Other statements:

Statement 2- Cystathionine synthase is involved in the production of cystathionine from homocysteine and serine. Pyridoxal phosphate (the active form of vitamin B6) is required for this reaction. Hence, in vitamin B6 deficiency, homocysteine levels are elevated.

Statement 3- Dihydrofolate reductase catalyzes the conversion of dihydrofolate and tetrahydrofolate. It is an NADPH-dependent reaction.

questions.text: 9. Which of the following cardiovascular parameters shows a significant change during normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Systemic vascular resistance is a cardiovascular parameter that decreases during normal pregnancy.

Systemic Vascular Resistance (SVR) decreases due to the relaxing effect of progesterone, nitric oxide, prostaglandins, or ANP on smooth muscle. Despite a large increase in cardiac output, maternal blood pressure decreases due to a decrease in SVR. There is an overall decrease in diastolic blood pressure and Mean Arterial Pressure by 5-10 mm Hg in mid-pregnancy; after that, a gradual rise occurs until term. 

Despite an increase in blood volume, heart rate, and cardiac output in pregnancy, measurements of central venous pressure (Option A), pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (Option B), and ejection fraction (Option C) do not change significantly.

Pearl PM1815: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

* The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min

* The apex is moved laterally 

* Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)

* X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)

* ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

* First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split

* Second heart sound: Normal but loud

* Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

* A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration

* A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)

* Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: 10. Which of the following is the most appropriate index for assessing overcrowding in a household?
questions.solution:
The "people per room" index is the standard and most widely used measure for assessing overcrowding in a household. It is simple, practical, and directly reflects how many individuals are sharing the available rooms meant for sleeping or living.

Overcrowding occurs when the house has more people than it can accommodate. This index is easy to apply in field surveys and correlates well with the risk of respiratory infections, mental health issues, and poor hygiene practices associated with congestion.

Other options:

Option A. People per house: Does not account for the number of rooms in the house and therefore does not accurately reflect the crowding level.

Option C. Floor area per person: This is a valid measure but is more complex and less commonly used in rapid surveys. It also varies with room layout and furniture.

Option D. Cubic space per house: This is a measure of ventilation, not overcrowding. It's used to assess air quality and room volume per person, not density.

Pearl PM1643: Overcrowding

Overcrowding is considered to exist if 2 persons over 9 years of age, not husband and wife, of opposite sexes are obliged to sleep in the same room.

The accepted standards against overcrowding are as follows.

questions.text:
11. A research study was conducted in a laboratory, focusing on a glycoprotein molecule extracted from the bone marrow of nude mice. This glycoprotein has been identified as playing a role in the body's immune response. A researcher then introduced enzymes X and Y to the extracted glycoprotein, observing the following outcomes:

With Enzyme X: Two soluble fragments and one insoluble fragment that crystallized in cold conditions.

With Enzyme Y: One large bivalent fragment and numerous smaller fragments

Identify enzymes X and Y, respectively.
questions.solution:
Papain and Pepsin are enzymes X and Y, respectively.

The glycoprotein extracted from the bone marrow that supports the body's immune response mostly indicates that it is an antibody molecule. The antibody involved in immune responses is immunoglobulin. When immunoglobulins undergo enzymatic digestion, various fragments are produced:

1. Papain: It cleaves the Ig molecule above the disulfide bridge in the hinge region, resulting in three fragments, each with a sedimentation coefficient of 3.5S, which involves two Fab fragments (soluble, bind to antigens) and one Fc fragment (insoluble, crystallizes in the cold)

2. Pepsin: It cleaves below the disulfide bridge in the hinge region, forming one F(ab')2 fragment with a sedimentation coefficient of 5S, composed of two Fab subunits bound together and multiple smaller fragments resulting from pepsin digestion of Fc into smaller pieces.

3. Mercaptoethanol: It generates four fragments—two heavy (H) chains and two light (L) chains—by cleaving only disulfide bonds, leaving peptide bonds intact.

questions.text: 12. A 28-year-old woman presents with primary infertility. She had two early pregnancy losses but has regular cycles with no dysmenorrhea. Physical examination is unremarkable. Imaging shows two endometrial echoes with a normal external uterine contour. MRI reveals a fibrous midline septum with 10° indentation and 10 mm depth. What is the most accurate diagnosis and management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, along with the imaging and hysteroscopic findings, point to a diagnosis of a septate uterus, which is managed by hysteroscopic metroplasty (septal resection), which significantly improves fertility outcomes and reduces miscarriage risk.

The diagnostic features in the vignette confirm a normal external uterine contour with two endometrial echoes on imaging, and the MRI shows indentation <10° with <10 mm depth, which is within the criteria for a septate uterus. 

A septate uterus is a congenital Müllerian anomaly caused by failure of resorption of the midline septum after fusion of the Müllerian ducts. The external uterine contour is normal, but the cavity is divided by a fibrous or fibromuscular septum that is typically thin and avascular, leading to poor implantation and recurrent miscarriages.

Diagnosis:

* Ultrasound (2D/3D USG): two endometrial echoes with normal external contour.

* Hysterosalpingography (HSG): shows a double endometrial cavity, cannot reliably distinguish from bicornuate uterus.

* MRI: gold standard for differentiating from bicornuate uterus – septum depth <10 mm, indentation angle <75°.

* Hysteroscopy: direct visualization of thin, avascular septum; often done with laparoscopy to exclude bicornuate uterus.

Other options:

Option A: Bicornuate uterus – Surgical correction is incorrect, because a bicornuate uterus typically shows an external fundal cleft >10 mm or an intercornual angle >105°. Here, the external contour is normal, excluding a bicornuate uterus. 

Option C: Septate uterus – Laparoscopic resection is incorrect, because a uterine septum lies inside the cavity and is best treated hysteroscopically. Laparoscopy has no role in the resection of a fibrous septum.

Option D: Didelphys uterus—Abdominal metroplasty is incorrect, since uterus didelphys shows two separate endometrial cavities and usually two cervices/vaginas, not a single cavity with a fibrous septum. Abdominal metroplasty is not used for this anomaly.

questions.text:
13. A 52-year-old chronic alcoholic man presented to the medical emergency with global confusion and double vision. You started infusing thiamine followed by dextrose. Thiamine is an integral part of an enzyme complex involved in the metabolism of glucose. Which is the correct reaction sequence of the components of this enzyme complex?

1.  Thiamine pyrophosphate 2.  Coenzyme A 3.  Lipoamide 4.  FAD 5.  NAD
questions.solution:
The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is a multienzyme complex involved, for which the correct sequence of components is 1, 3, 2, 4, 5.

Pyruvate dehydrogenase converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. It includes three enzymes:

E1- Pyruvate dehydrogenase

E2- Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase

E3- Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase.



Chronic alcoholics often experience thiamine deficiency due to impaired absorption, leading to Wernicke's (ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, encephalopathy) and Korsakoff's (amnesia with confabulation) syndromes. This deficiency also impairs pyruvate oxidation, causing lactic and pyruvic acidosis.

questions.text: 14. All of the following are likely to be present in thallium poisoning except?
questions.solution:
Hematopoietic abnormalities like leukopenia or thrombocytopenia are not characteristic features of thallium toxicity.

Thallium is considered an ideal homicidal poison because poisoning with thallium resembles natural death. Thallium sulfate and thallium acetate are the two salts of thallium used in dyes, in the glass industry, and as rodenticides and pesticides. The toxic effects of thallium are due to its high affinity for sulfhydryl groups and its interference with potassium-dependent enzymes, sparing the hematopoietic system. 

Mild cases of poisoning have features of joint pain, loss of appetite, and drowsiness. Severe cases present with colic, vomiting, muscle pain, and convulsions. Psychosis, tremors, delirium, and coma are seen in severe cases.

Alopecia is typically observed after 2 weeks, and a characteristic feature is the loss of the outer third of the eyebrows. A brownish- black pigmentation near the hair roots is characteristic. Mees' lines can also be seen on the nails. Maculopapular rashes in a butterfly pattern on the face are characteristic of this condition. It can also present with stocking-glove neuropathy, paresthesias, and cranial nerve involvement.

Treatment is mainly by stomach wash with potassium iodide or prussian blue and activated charcoal. Hemodialysis is useful within 48 hours.

questions.text: 15. What is the function of the structure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows a proteasome, and its function is protein degradation. 

The proteasome is a cylindrical structure in the cytosol. It has a central core with proteolytic enzymes. It works via the ubiquitin–proteasome pathway, where proteins tagged with ubiquitin are recognized and degraded into short peptides inside the proteasome’s catalytic core. This process regulates cell cycle, apoptosis, immune responses, and protein quality control. It plays an important role in antigen presentation to T lymphocytes as it degrades viruses and other molecules to small peptides.



Other options:

Option A. Protein folding is carried out by molecular chaperones (e.g., HSP70, HSP90) that help polypeptides attain correct conformation. 

Option B. Post-translational modification, which includes phosphorylation, glycosylation, acetylation, and others, is mediated by enzymes in the cytoplasm, endoplasmic reticulum, or Golgi apparatus. 

Option D. Protein sorting is directed by the Golgi apparatus, which sends proteins to lysosomes, membranes, or secretory pathways.

Pearl PM1401: Structure of proteins

questions.text:
16. An elderly man who is a known case of CHF is operated on for cholelithiasis electively. On POD 1, he complained of difficulty in breathing and a fever since morning. His chest X-ray is given below. Which of these preoperative instructions is incorrect?

CHF - Congestive heart failure  POD - Postoperative day

choices.text: Cessation of smoking 4 weeks prior to surgery
Nebulization on the night before surgery
Adequate control of CHF prior to surgery

questions.solution:
Incentive spirometry done only postoperatively is an incorrect statement regarding the prevention of this condition.

The chest X-ray is showing a right upper lobe lung collapse into a triangular opacity with raised right hemidiaphragm. The presence of fever on post-operative day 1, with chest X-ray showing collapse points towards lung atelectasis. Chest physiotherapy in the form of incentive spirometry is useful in preventing atelectasis both pre- and postoperatively. 

Atelectasis is the most common respiratory complication following surgery. It results from partial or complete collapse of alveoli and is often triggered by general anaesthesia and upper abdominal or thoracic surgery, which impair diaphragmatic movement. The pathophysiology includes decreased lung compliance due to reduced FRC and the accumulation of endobronchial secretions, leading to ventilation-perfusion mismatch and intrapulmonary shunting.

Prevention of postoperative atelectasis can be done by: 

* Chest physiotherapy 

* Incentive spirometry

* Cessation of smoking 4-6 weeks before surgery (Option B)

* Nebulization with bronchodilators the night before surgery (Option C)

* Steam inhalation

* Adequate analgesia

* Treat underlying conditions like CCF and COPD before surgery (Option D)

Risk factors include smoking, obesity, and preexisting pulmonary conditions, which impair mucociliary clearance and reduce the ability to effectively clear secretions. Clinically, atelectasis is the most common cause of early postoperative fever. Other signs include tachypnea, decreased oxygen saturation, and use of accessory respiratory muscles. Breath sounds may be diminished, absent, or bronchial in nature. Chest X-ray shows loss of the hemidiaphragm, reduced lung volume, air bronchograms, or tracheal deviation toward the affected side in severe cases.

Atelectasis is often reversible within the first 24 to 48 hours postoperatively with interventions such as early mobilisation, deep breathing exercises (e.g., five breaths held for 5–6 seconds), incentive spirometry, coughing, chest physiotherapy, bronchodilators, adequate hydration, and suctioning of secretions when necessary.

Adequate pain control is essential for effective pulmonary rehabilitation, and is best achieved through a multimodal approach using acetaminophen, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), opioids as needed, or regional anaesthesia techniques.

questions.text: 17. A 32-year-old woman presents for her first antenatal visit at 12 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history includes a live baby born at 39 weeks of gestation, twins born at 34 weeks of gestation via cesarean section, and a spontaneous abortion at 10 weeks of gestation. What is her GTPAL score?
questions.solution:
The GTPAL score for a 32-year-old woman at 12 weeks of gestation is: G4T1P1A1L3

Gravida (G) = 4: 4 total pregnancies Term (T) = 1: 1 pregnancy delivered at 37 weeks or later  Preterm (P) = 1: 1 pregnancy delivered less than 37 weeks Abortions (A) = 1: 1 spontaneous abortion Living (L) = 3: 3 living children (1 from a vaginal delivery, 2 from twins).

The GTPAL obstetric score is used to summarise the past obstetric history of a pregnant woman: 

G - Denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one T - Any delivery that happens at or beyond 37 weeks P - Number of deliveries that happen less than 37 weeks A - Abortion - any pregnancy loss that occurs before 20 weeks. This includes induced abortions, spontaneous miscarriages, and ectopic pregnancies L - Living children at present

Note: Multifetal pregnancy is counted as one for both gravida and term/preterm delivery.

questions.text: 18. While evaluating a child with glomerulonephritis, you notice the renal biopsy specimens show ANCA-positive glomerulonephritis with the absence of granulomatous inflammation. Which of the following small vessel vasculitis is this child likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of microscopic polyangiitis. The absence of granulomatous inflammation differentiates microscopic polyangiitis from other forms of ANCA-associated vasculitis. 

Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA)-associated vasculitis is categorized into 3 distinct forms: 

* Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA; formerly Wegener granulomatosis)

* Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA)

* Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, formerly called Churg–Strauss syndrome (CSS) 

Necrotizing vasculitis is the cardinal histologic feature in both GPA and MPA. Kidney biopsies typically demonstrate crescentic glomerulonephritis with little or no immune complex deposition. hence the name “pauci-immune vasculitis.”

Granulomatous inflammation is typically absent in MPA but is common in both GPA and CSS.

ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV) comprises a group of multi-systemic diseases affecting small-to-medium-sized vessels. It is characterized by the presence of ANCA with specificity for either proteinase-3 (PR3) or myeloperoxidase (MPO).

Other options:

Option A: Wegener granulomatosis: It is now known as Granulomatosis with polyangiitis(GPA). It is a necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis affecting the small and medium-sized vessels. It usually targets the respiratory tracts(both upper and lower) and the kidneys.

Option C: Churg-Strauss syndrome: It is necrotizing granulomatous small vessel vasculitis with a history of bronchial asthma and peripheral eosinophilia.

Option D: Henoch–Schonlein purpura: It is the most common vasculitis of childhood. It is characterized by leukocytoclastic vasculitis and IgA deposition in the skin, kidney, joints, and GIT. The clinical manifestations include palpable purpura, joint involvement in the form of arthritis or arthralgias, diarrhea, vomiting, renal involvement in the form of microscopic hematuria, proteinuria, etc.

questions.text: 19. A patient presented with 6 days of fever, dyspnea, and productive cough. Physical examination reveals decreased air entry and stony dullness on percussion over the right lung. Laboratory investigations showed leucocytosis. A chest X-ray was performed as shown. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and chest x-ray suggest a diagnosis of parapneumonic effusion. 

Parapneumonic effusions (PPEs) are frequently observed in patients diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia. These effusions are typically reactive, meaning no organisms are identified on culture. Patients presenting with PPEs commonly present with fever, pleuritic chest pain, productive cough, and leukocytosis with decreased air entry and stony dullness. When initially evaluating a patient with bacterial pneumonia, the possibility of a PPE should always be considered.

Chest X-ray shows a large pleural effusion obscuring the costophrenic angle with minimal pulmonary infiltrates. Thoracentesis is indicated to rule out infection of the pleural space if a significant amount of pleural fluid is present.

Indications for pleural evacuation:

* Loculated pleural fluid

* Pleural fluid pH <7.20

* Pleural fluid glucose <3.3 mmol/L (<60 mg/dL)

* Positive Gram stain or culture of the pleural fluid

* Presence of gross pus in the pleural space

* Elevated pleural fluid LDH (>900 IU/L)

Other options: 

Option B. Hydropneumothorax presents with an air-fluid level on chest X-ray. Rupture of the cavity in pulmonary tuberculosis could be the cause of hydropneumothorax (shown below). The pleural fluid is typically purulent, thick, and rich in lymphocytes. Acid-fast smears and mycobacterial cultures frequently yield positive results, and surgical drainage is usually necessary.



Option C. Lung abscess manifests as cavitations and necrosis following a microbial infection. Symptoms include fever, foul-smelling sputum, chest pain, night sweats, fatigue, and anemia. Physical examination may reveal poor dentition, cavernous breath sounds on lung auscultation, and digital clubbing. Below is the chest X-ray showing lung abscess cavitations.



Option D. Acute respiratory distress syndrome is an acute (less than 1 week) clinical syndrome characterized by severe, rapid-onset dyspnea, hypoxemia, and diffuse bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, ultimately resulting in respiratory failure.

questions.text: 20. Which of the following change in the eye structures does not happen during accommodation?

choices.text: Movement of ciliary body forwards and inwards

questions.solution:
During accommodation, the tension on the zonular ligaments is relaxed.

Accommodation:

* The phenomenon of increasing the convergence power by augmenting the refractive power of the lens and thereby increasing its curvature is called accommodation.

* Steps in accommodation

* The capsule of the lens is more elastic than the lens itself.

* When the circular fibres of the ciliary muscles contract, the ciliary body approaches the lens (forwards and inwards towards the optical axis).

* This slackens the zonules so that the capsule, relieved of its tension, is able to mound the lens to its accommodative form (assumes a more convex shape for focusing closer objects).

questions.text: 21. A 26-year-old man presents with painful ulcers on his penis. Examination revealed lesions with 'kissing ulcers' appearance and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Which of the following images represents the microscopic appearance of a smear from these lesions?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of chancroid. A smear from the lesion would reveal the presence of the gram-negative coccobacillus Haemophilus ducreyi, showing school of fish/railroad track appearance, as seen in image 1.

Chancroid is a type of sexually transmitted infection (STI) that is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi, a gram-negative coccobacillus. It presents with painful genital ulceration along with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy that may develop into buboes. Auto-inoculation by the organism can result in new ulcers merging with the older ones. Hence, they are called "kissing ulcers."



Other options:

Option B: Multinucleated giant cells are seen on Tzanck smear in herpes genitalis. These ulcers are caused by herpes simplex type 2 virus and present as a cluster of vesicles on an erythematous base, with painful inguinal lymph nodes.

A Tzanck smear is shown below:



Option C: Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale, which is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly Calymmatobacterium granulomatis). It presents with painless beefy red ulcers. Inguinal lymph nodes are not usually enlarged, but the infection can spread subcutaneously and give the appearance of "pseudo buboes". The diagnosis is made by Giemsa staining, which shows the Donovan bodies. They show bipolar staining ("safety-pin appearance").

The image below shows Donovan bodies in a white blood cell:



Option D: Spirochetes are seen on dark-field microscopy in syphilitic ulcers. They are caused by Treponema pallidum and present with a single, painless genital ulcer with painless inguinal lymphadenopathy. 

Darkfield microscopy with spirochetes is shown below:

questions.text: 22. A patient presented with increased fatigue and pallor with Hb - 8.0 mg/dl was followed up for a bone marrow aspirate, which is shown below. Which of the following cannot be the cause of the given presentation?
questions.solution:
The given image shows ringed sideroblasts in a bone marrow aspirate, which are not caused by methylcobalamin deficiency. 

Ringed sideroblasts are erythroid progenitors characterized by iron-laden mitochondria, which appear as blue perinuclear granules when stained with Prussian blue.

questions.text: 23. What stage of a testicular tumor can involve superficial inguinal lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
The T4 stage of a testicular tumor can involve the superficial inguinal lymph nodes. 

Testicular tumors commonly metastasize to the retroperitoneal lymphatics. Lymphatic drainage from the testes flows to the para-aortic lymph nodes, located near the origin of the gonadal vessels.

The lymphatics from the skin of the scrotum and penis drain to the superficial inguinal lymph node, so the inguinal lymph nodes are only affected if the scrotal skin is involved. In the T4 stage of testicular cancer tumor spreads to invade the scrotum.

questions.text: 24. During the third stage of labor, a house surgeon is conducting a delivery. The postgraduate doctor points to the umbilical cord and asks about Wharton's Jelly. What type of connective tissue is Wharton's jelly?
questions.solution:
Wharton's jelly is a type of mucoid connective tissue, the main component of the fetal umbilical cord.

Wharton's jelly is a gelatinous mucoid connective tissue, is most prevalent around the umbilical cord's blood vessels and contains a small cell population. It is rich in ground substance, primarily composed of hyaluronan, and features scattered fibroblasts and a few collagen fibers. Among these fibroblastic cells are numerous mesenchymal stem cells.

Other Options:

Option A. Areolar tissue/loose connective tissue is characterized by a higher proportion of ground substance compared to collagen. It commonly encases small blood vessels and is found in regions adjacent to various types of epithelium.

Option B. Dense connective tissue has fewer cells and more type I collagen fibers than ground substance. It comes in two forms, regular (tendons, aponeuroses, ligaments) and irregular (deep dermis, organ capsules).

Option C. Reticular connective tissue, rich in delicate networks of type III collagen fibers, is predominantly found in lymphoid organs. These fibers serve as crucial attachment sites for lymphocytes and other immune cells.

questions.text: 25. A young man presents with multiple mucosal ulcers. On examination, Nikolsky sign is positive. Immunofluorescence microscopy shows the following finding. Which of the following is the most common target antigen for the antibodies in this disease?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the immunofluorescence showing the intercellular deposition of antibodies around the keratinocytes is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris. Desmoglein 3 is the most common target antigen for the antibodies in pemphigus vulgaris.

Pemphigus vulgaris is caused due to the production of antibodies mainly against desmoglein 3. Rarely, antibodies against desmoglein 1 can also be found. The antibodies are commonly IgG antibodies.

Desmoglein 3 is mainly present in the basal and suprabasal layers of the skin and mucosa. The patients, therefore, present with flaccid bullae over the skin and mucosal ulcerations. Patients show a positive Nikolsky sign (on applying the pressure, the epidermis separates from the dermis).

Oral mucosa is commonly affected. Other areas where ulceration can be seen are the conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, etc. Cutaneous lesions are more common over the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

Direct immunofluorescence will show the deposition of antibodies around the keratinocytes in the epidermis.

It is treated with steroids, azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, rituximab, etc.

Other options:

Option A: Antibodies against desmoglein 1 are mainly seen in pemphigus foliaceous. They are visible as scattered, scaly lesions involving the seborrheic areas of the scalp, face, chest, and upper back. Mucosal involvement is not seen in this condition.

Option C: Desmoglein 2 is not a target for the antibodies in immunobullous diseases.

Option D: Antibodies against desmoplakin are found in paraneoplastic pemphigus. The lesion is commonly associated with non‐Hodgkin lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, Castleman disease, thymoma, and Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia. It is characterized by stomatitis; conjunctivitis that may lead to scarring; and esophageal, genital mucosal, and flexural involvement, with bullous and erosive lesions.

questions.text: 26. A middle-aged woman presented to the emergency department with signs of shock. Upon further investigations, a diagnosis of a ruptured tubo-ovarian mass was made. At what stage of pelvic inflammatory disease is she in?
questions.solution:
The ruptured tubo-ovarian mass belongs to stage IV of pelvic inflammatory diseases. It usually presents with a sudden worsening of the patient's condition.

Tubo ovarian abscess is a complication of acute pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). It can be unilateral or bilateral and is characterized by dull or sharp abdominal pain. It is associated with other features like fever and an adnexal mass. On auscultation, a frictional rub can be heard throughout all quadrants of the abdomen which can be suggestive of a ruptured ovarian abscess. 

Treatment involves the administration of parenteral antibiotics till the patient has been afebrile for at least 24 hours. Following this, oral doxycycline with either metronidazole or clindamycin is given for 14 days. Ruptured abscess is treated surgically.

Acute salpingitis with peritonitis—purulent discharge

questions.text: 27. A 45-year-old man with Down's syndrome is brought to the Medicine OPD by his sister who complains that he has been easily confused and forgetful about his daily activities recently. A provisional diagnosis of Alzheimer’s disease is made. Which of the following genes is primarily responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
The key clue here is Down’s syndrome (Trisomy 21) with early-onset dementia. The gene responsible is the APP gene (amyloid precursor protein), which is located on chromosome 21.

Because individuals with Down syndrome carry an extra copy of chromosome 21, there is a triplication of the APP gene. This leads to overproduction of β-amyloid, causing early accumulation of amyloid plaques in the brain. As a result, almost all patients with Down syndrome develop Alzheimer’s-type neuropathology by middle age, with dementia symptoms typically appearing in the 40s.

Alzheimer’s disease is associated with mutations in chromosomes 1, 14, 19, and 21.

Other options:

Option B. Presenilin-1 (PS-1) gene is located on chromosome 14. Mutations in PS1 are the most common cause of autosomal dominant familial early-onset Alzheimer’s disease. They increase production of amyloid-β42, which aggregates into senile plaques. However, this mutation is inherited in families and is not related to Down syndrome.

Option C. Presenilin-2 (PS-2) gene is located on chromosome 1. Mutations in PS2 also cause familial early-onset Alzheimer’s, though they are much rarer than PS1 mutations. Like PS1, they lead to enhanced amyloid-β deposition. 

Option D. Superoxide dismutase (SOD1) gene is also located on chromosome 21, like APP. However, mutations in SOD1 are associated with familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), not Alzheimer’s disease.

Pearl PM0404: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

* Age of onset > 60 years

* Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24

* Diagnosis: Clinical

* 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits

* Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function

* No disturbance in consciousness

* Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

* Most important risk factor: Old age

* Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

* Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)

* Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)

* Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)

* Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline

* Anosognosia 

* Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)

* Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

* Psychotic symptoms: delusions

* Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks

* Lack of insight regarding deficits

* Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures

* disrupted sleep - wake pattern.

* Urinary incontinence.

* Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

* Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.



CT/MRI:

* Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

* NMDA antagonist: memantine

* Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.

* Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: 28. A 32-year-old woman with a history of recurrent pregnancy loss presents for evaluation. Which of the following findings is not considered a valid criterion under the revised Sapporo/Sydney criteria for Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS)?

choices.text: Three or more consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks of gestation
Premature birth before 34 weeks due to preeclampsia
Single positive test for lupus anticoagulant
Presence of anti-β2 glycoprotein-I antibodies on two occasions, 12 weeks apart

questions.solution:
A single positive test for lupus anticoagulant is not a part of the revised Sapporo/Sydney criteria. 

APS is an autoimmune, prothrombotic disorder characterized by vascular thrombosis and/or pregnancy morbidity in the presence of persistent antiphospholipid antibodies. It may occur as a primary condition or as a secondary condition to systemic lupus erythematosus.

The revised Sapporo/Sydney criteria (2006) require:

* At least one clinical criterion (vascular thrombosis or pregnancy morbidity), AND

* At least one laboratory criterion (antiphospholipid antibodies)

Clinical criteria include:

* ≥3 consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks (after ruling out other causes). (Option A)

* ≥1 unexplained fetal death ≥10 weeks.

* ≥1 premature birth before 34 weeks due to preeclampsia, eclampsia, or placental insufficiency. (Option B)

* Vascular thrombosis (arterial, venous, or small-vessel).

Laboratory criteria include:

* Lupus anticoagulant (on ≥2 occasions, 12 weeks apart).

* Anticardiolipin antibodies (IgG/IgM, medium or high titer, on ≥2 occasions).

* Anti-β2 glycoprotein I antibodies (IgG/IgM, on ≥2 occasions, 12 weeks apart) (Option D)

questions.text: 29. Which of the following enzymes is not implicated in the formation of neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs)?
questions.solution:
DNAse I is not implicated in the formation of neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs).

Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are extracellular fibrillar networks that are produced by neutrophils in response to infections and inflammation, responsible for concentrating antimicrobial substances at the site of infections, thus helping to prevent their spread. 

NET formation involves three enzymes that cause chromatin decondensation. It starts with activation of an arginine deaminase (ROS-dependent), followed by myeloperoxidase (MPO) and neutrophil elastase, which enter the nucleus and cause further chromatin decondensation. 

DNase I degrades NETs, not forms them. It's used by the body to clear NETs in circulation and prevent excessive inflammation. The digestion of DNA by DNase1 and DNase1L3 is the rate-limiting factor for NET accumulation. Mutations occurring in one of these two DNase genes determine anti-DNA formation and are associated with severe lupus-like syndromes and lupus nephritis (LN).

questions.text: 30. A 70-year-old female who is on symptomatic therapy for osteoarthritis for 15 years came to the hospital with complaints of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and dyspepsia. Endoscopy showed gastric mucosal inflammation and ulcer. Which of the following drugs is approved by the FDA for the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is likely to be on NSAIDs as a symptomatic therapy for osteoarthritis. The drug approved by the FDA for NSAID-induced gastric ulcers is a PGE1 analogue (misoprostol), which protects the gastric mucosa and promotes healing.

NSAIDs inhibit COX-1 and COX-2, leading to decreased prostaglandin (especially PGE1) synthesis in the gastric mucosa. PGE1 analogues replace the protective prostaglandins, promoting:

* Increased mucus and bicarbonate secretion

* Improved mucosal blood flow

* Inhibition of gastric acid secretion

Other options:

Option B. PGD2 antagonist (Fevipiprant) blocks PGD2 receptors have no established role in gastric mucosal protection. PGD2 primarily regulates inflammation and vasodilation, and antagonists are not used for the treatment or prevention of NSAID-induced ulcers

Option C. PGD2 agonists stimulate pathways that are not involved in gastric mucosal defense.

Option D. PGF2 analogues are mainly used in ophthalmology (e.g., Latanoprost-glaucoma treatment) and obstetrics (Carboprost-uterotonic action). They do not enhance gastric mucosal protection or healing.

questions.text:
31. Match drug administration routes with their characteristic features.

1. Intravenous route a. Least bioavailability
2. Subcutaneous route b. Not for oily preparations
3. Intramuscular route c. Contraindicated in anticoagulant therapy
4. Oral route d. Pain or necrosis from irritating substances
questions.solution:
The correct match is 

1. Intravenous route b. Not for oily preparations
2. Subcutaneous route d. Pain or necrosis from irritating substances
3. Intramuscular route c. Contraindicated in anticoagulant therapy
4. Oral route a. Least bioavailability


 

The intravenous route, having 100% (equal to 1) bioavailability, is suitable for emergencies, allows for precise dosage titration, essential for high-molecular-weight protein and peptide drugs. Intravenous administration generally requires slow injection and is therefore not suitable for oily preparations or poorly soluble substances. 

The subcutaneous route has a bioavailability between 0.75-1, is rapidly absorbed from aqueous solutions, and is suitable for certain poorly soluble suspensions and for administering slow-release implants. It is not suitable for large volumes; it may cause pain or tissue damage with irritating substances

The intramuscular route has a bioavailability between 0.75-1, is rapidly absorbed from aqueous solutions, and is suitable for moderate volumes, oily vehicles, and some irritating substances. It is contraindicated during anticoagulant therapy due to increased risk of muscle hematoma and bleeding, and may affect the interpretation of certain diagnostic tests like creatine kinase. 

Oral ingestion route bioavailability is between 0.05 - 1, less than other routes. Absorption is highly variable and considered the most convenient and economical, and safer route. It requires good patient adherence.

questions.text: 32. A 34-year-old woman presents with blurred vision and difficulty focusing in her right eye. Examination reveals a dilated pupil that is sluggishly reactive to light and a slow near response. Knee-jerk reflex is impaired. What causes these characteristic eye findings?
questions.solution:
The clinical examination findings are indicative of light-near dissociation of Adie’s syndrome caused by the denervation of the sphincter pupillae. 

Adie syndrome results from the denervation of the postganglionic parasympathetic supply to the sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscle, often occurring after a viral illness.

The affected pupil would be larger in size compared to the other and shows sluggish constriction on light reflex and sluggish response to convergence. Instillation of a small percentage of 0.1% pilocarpine can also induce constriction in an Adies pupil. Association includes absent or diminished knee reflexes due to dysfunction of the dorsal root ganglion seen in Holmes-Adie syndrome. 

Other options:

Option A. Temporal lobe infarct presents with aphasia (involvement of Wernicke’s area), seizures, auditory hallucinations, and vestibular dysfunction.

Option C. In oculomotor nerve palsy, the pupil is fixed and dilated. In addition, extraocular palsy (other than the lateral rectus and superior oblique) is seen, resulting in a down and out position of the eye and ptosis. 

Option D. Dorsal midbrain lesion is seen in neurosyphilis, causing Argyll-Robertson pupil by interrupting the pupillary light reflex pathway and spares the ventral pupillary near reflex pathway, resulting in light-near dissociation, pupils constrict on near vision, but in light, neither pupil constricts.

* Pontine hemorrhage

* Horner's syndrome

* Old age

* Argyll Robertson pupil

* Drugs and poisons (opiates, organophosphates)

Causes of dilated pupils include

* Holmes–Adie (myotonic) pupil

* Third nerve palsy

* Atropine

* Carbon monoxide

* Ethylene glycol

questions.text: 33. A CNS lymphoma patient on high-dose methotrexate and leucovorin developed reduced urine output and impaired renal function after 48 hours. Despite hydration, alkalization, and high-dose leucovorin, the methotrexate levels are still 1.1 micromoles. What is the next best treatment option?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a patient having methotrexate (MTX) toxicity for which glucarpidase therapy is the next best treatment when high levels persist despite hydration, alkalinization, and high-dose leucovorin (100mg/m2). 

Glucarpidase is an FDA-approved MTX-cleaving enzyme and can be used to treat MTX toxicity. This recombinant bacterial carboxypeptidase G2 converts MTX into less toxic metabolites—glutamate and 2,4-diamino-N(10)-methylpteroic acid—which are then excreted by the liver. Plasma MTX concentrations decrease by 99% or more within 5 to 15 minutes of enzyme administration.

Methotrexate is a folic acid analogue used in treating various cancers and rheumatological and gynecological conditions. It inhibits DNA replication by interfering with tetrahydrofolate metabolism, binding to the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase. This action reduces the cellular capacity for one-carbon transfer and methylation reactions essential for synthesizing purine ribonucleotides and TMP.

High-dose methotrexate (HDM-L) administration carries a risk of renal toxicity, likely due to the drug's precipitation as a weak acid in acidic tubular fluid. To mitigate this, vigorous hydration and alkalinization of urine pH are crucial before administering the MTX. If MTX levels at 48 hours post-administration are 1 μM or higher, high leucovorin doses/folinic acid (100 mg/m²) can be given until plasma MTX concentrations fall below 50 nM.

With proper hydration, urine alkalinization, and normal renal function, the incidence of nephrotoxicity after HDM-L is less than 2%. For oliguric patients, intermittent hemodialysis is ineffective in reducing MTX levels. However, continuous-flow hemodialysis can clear MTX at approximately 50% of the rate observed in patients with healthy renal function. Alternatively, glucarpidase can be used to treat MTX toxicity.

questions.text: 34. A young female presented with complaints of frequent burning micturation along with fever, chills, fatigue and headache. Mid-stream urine sample was collected, and microscopy showed short chains of oval cocci arranged at an angle to each other. On sheep blood agar, non-hemolytic colonies were detected. Growth was seen on the culture media, as shown in the image. Identify the organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette, along with the presence of non-hemolytic cocci present in a chain at an angle to each other and showing growth on a bile esculin agar, points towards a diagnosis of urinary tract infection caused by Enterococcus faecalis. 

Enterococci are part of the normal flora of the human intestine, biliary tract, vagina and male urethra. E. faecalis is the most common species found in clinical specimens, whereas E. faecium is more drug-resistant than E. faecalis. Enterococci are gram-positive oval cocci, arranged in pairs at an angle to each other. They are non-hemolytic, PYR test (pyrrolidonyl-beta-naphthylamide) positive and show growth on bile esculin agar. They can grow in extremes of conditions like 6.5% NaCl, 40% bile, and at a pH of 9.6.

Enterococci are one of the major hospital-acquired pathogens, producing various infections like urinary tract infections, bacteremia and mitral valve endocarditis(in intravenous drug abusers), intrabdominal, pelvic and soft tissue infections, and late-onset neonatal meningitis and sepsis. They are intrinsically resistant to cephalosporins and offer low-level resistance to some aminoglycosides.

An approach to the diagnosis of Gram-positive cocci is given below:



Other options:

Option A: Streptococcus mutans is mainly part of the oral flora and causes dental caries or endocarditis, not urinary tract infections, and its colonies are typically α-hemolytic.

Option C: Staphylococcus saprophyticus can cause UTIs in young females, but it is a gram-positive cocci in clusters (not chains) and is usually novobiocin-resistant, differentiating it from Enterococcus.

Option D: Staphylococcus epidermidis is a skin commensal that forms clusters, not chains, and is primarily associated with infections of prosthetic devices.

questions.text: 35. Barrel-shaped arthroconidia as depicted in the below image is a feature of _______
questions.solution:
Coccidioides immitis produces barrel-shaped arthroconidia in culture. These are thick-walled, rectangular arthroconidia, separated by empty disjunctor cells, which gives them a barrel or boxcar appearance.

Coccidioides immitis is a dimorphic fungus that exists in two distinct forms, saprophytic and parasitic.

At 25°C (saprophytic phase), it exists as septate hyphae that fragment into arthroconidia with a barrel-like appearance, which are the infectious forms inhaled by humans. In tissue at 37°C (parasitic phase), the arthroconidia enlarge to form spherules containing endospores, a key diagnostic clue.

The infection can be asymptomatic, or patients may present with symptoms like fever, cough, and pleuritic chest pain. It is also referred to as Valley fever. Some clinical features result from an immunologic response. These include toxic erythema, erythema nodosum, and erythema multiforme. Symmetrical arthralgias, also known as "Desert rheumatism," may also be observed. Clinical dissemination of infection outside the thoracic cavity occurs in immunocompromised patients. 

Other options:

Option A. Blastomyces dermatitidis is also a dimorphic fungus. In tissues, it exists as a large yeast with broad-based budding and thick refractile walls, which is diagnostic. In culture, it grows as mold and produces conidia on short stalks. It does not produce arthroconidia. Clinical disease (blastomycosis) often presents with lung involvement and ulcerative skin lesions.

Option C. Epidermophyton floccosum is a dermatophyte responsible for superficial mycoses (tinea infections). It produces club-shaped, smooth-walled macroconidia in clusters, with the absence of microconidia.

Option D. Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis, mimicking tuberculosis clinically. In tissues, it appears as small (2–5 µm), oval, intracellular yeast within macrophages. In culture, it produces tuberculate macroconidia (knob-like projections).

* Mycelial growth showing spherical spores, which are large (8-10 μm size) and thick-walled, with tubercular projections.

* Tiny oval yeast cells (2-4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 



2. Blastomyces: Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 



3. Coccidoides: Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20-80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 



4. Paracoccidioides: Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: 36. Which of the following conditions may have the following ascitic fluid findings - Serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) 1.1g/dL and ascitic protein 2.5 g/dL?
questions.solution:
Cirrhosis is characterized by SAAG >1.1 and ascitic protein < 2.5 g/dL.

Serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG):

* Calculated by subtracting the ascitic albumin concentration from the serum albumin level.

* Reflects the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids

* SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It reflects the presence of portal hypertension.

* SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy.

Ascitic protein level analysis further helps in identifying the etiology, in cases with high SAAG (≥1.1):

* ≥2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing the passage of protein into the ascites. eg. cardiac ascites

* <2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein. Eg. cirrhosis

The serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is the most reli­able method to differentiate causes of ascites due to portal hyper­tension from those not due to portal hypertension.

questions.text: 37. Which of the following sets includes only themes that are part of the strategic priority areas of the Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK)?

choices.text: Reproductive health – Mental health – Vocational training
Non-communicable diseases – Substance misuse – Mental health

questions.solution:
Non-communicable diseases, substance misuse, and mental health are included in the strategic priority of RKSK.

These are the key adolescent health issues addressed by RKSK:

* Nutrition – Preventing malnutrition and anemia (WIFS, deworming, diet counselling).

* Sexual and Reproductive Health (SRH) – Menstrual hygiene, delay of marriage, STI/RTI awareness.

* Non-communicable diseases (NCDs) – Early prevention and awareness of risk factors.

* Substance misuse – Prevention and counselling for tobacco, alcohol, and drug use.

* Injuries and violence (including Gender-based violence) – Prevention, safe behaviors, and support systems.

* Mental health – Early identification, basic counselling, and referral.

The Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK) is a national adolescent health program launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) in January 2014.

RKSK adopts a holistic approach to adolescent health, moving beyond the earlier emphasis on reproductive and sexual health to include psychosocial, preventive, and promotive services. It introduces peer-led interventions at the community level through trained Saathiyas (peer educators) and strengthens facility-based services via Adolescent Friendly Health Clinics (AFHCs).

RKSK ensures adolescents are reached in both in-school and out-of-school settings, covering married and unmarried, urban and rural, and marginalized groups through a gender-sensitive and equity-focused framework.

Other options:

Option A. WASH (Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene) and immunization are not part of RKSK’s six strategic areas; they're covered under other programs (e.g., Swachh Bharat Mission and UIP).

Option B. Vocational training is addressed under skill development schemes, not RKSK.

Option C. Sanitation and family planning are not RKSK strategic themes; they're part of RMNCH+A and Swachh Bharat Mission, respectively.

questions.text: 38. A baby born at 32 weeks of gestation developed tachypnea, grunting, and cyanosis. Chest X-ray revealed a ground-glass appearance and air bronchogram. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with chest x-ray showing ground-glass appearance and air bronchogram is consistent with the diagnosis of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

Respiratory distress syndrome (hyaline membrane disease) is primarily seen in premature infants. It is commonly seen before 28 weeks, followed by 32-36 weeks, and is rare after 37 weeks.

Risk factors for RDS include:

* Maternal diabetes

* Multiple births

* Cesarean section

* Precipitous delivery

* Asphyxia

* Maternal history of previously affected infants

The primary cause of RDS is reduced production and secretion of surfactant. It leads to an increase in surface tension and alveolar collapse.

The clinical features include tachypnea, prominent expiratory grunting, intercostal and subcostal retractions, nasal flaring, and cyanosis. They usually appear within minutes of birth. 

Chest radiograph shows diffuse, fine reticular granularity of the parenchyma known as ground-glass appearance and air bronchogram.

Nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP) is the initial intervention in infants with RDS or in infants at risk of RDS without respiratory failure. Oxygen therapy with warm, humidified oxygen is provided to maintain a target SpO2 of 91-95%. 

Mechanical ventilation is indicated in infants with respiratory failure or persistent apnea. 

Prevention is possible by antenatal administration of betamethasone or dexamethasone before 37 weeks is recommended in preterm labor, as it reduces the incidence and mortality of RDS.

Other options:

Option B: Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is a self-limiting clinical condition caused by delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid. Early-onset tachypnea, expiratory grunting or retractions, and occasional cyanosis are the characteristic findings. 

The chest radiograph reveals prominent perihilar pulmonary vascular markings and fluid in the interlobar fissures. It is distinguished from RDS by its rapid recovery and the absence of radiographic findings of RDS.

The image given below is the chest radiograph seen in the transient tachypnea of the newborn.



Option C: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) occurs secondary to a structural defect of the diaphragm and is associated with pulmonary hypoplasia. Babies present with tachypnea, grunting, use of accessory muscles, cyanosis, and scaphoid abdomen. The chest radiograph shows bowel loops in the thorax and the contralateral mediastinal shift.

The image given below is the chest radiograph showing multiple gas shadows in the thorax, indicating congenital diaphragmatic hernia.



Option D: Meconium aspiration syndrome is the passage of meconium into the amniotic fluid due to fetal distress and hypoxia that gets aspirated into the lungs. It usually occurs in term or post-term infants. The clinical features include tachypnea, retractions, grunting, and cyanosis. The chest radiograph reveals bilateral streaky densities, hyperinflation, flattening of the diaphragm, and atelectasis.

The image given below is the chest radiograph seen in meconium aspiration syndrome.

questions.text: 39. A pediatrician informs that in a hypothermic newborn, a protein in brown adipose tissue generates heat by uncoupling oxidative phosphorylation. Which of the following best describes the effect of the uncoupling protein?

choices.text: ↑ electron transport & O2 consumption, no ATP production
Normal electron transport and ↓ O2 consumption

questions.solution:
Thermogenin is the uncoupler protein present in the brown adipose tissue in newborns. It increases electron transport & O2 consumption, but no ATP production.

Thermogenin acts as an uncoupler, meaning it creates a proton leak across the inner mitochondrial membrane. This bypasses ATP synthase V. As a result, the electron transport chain (ETC) accelerates to re-establish the proton gradient and consumes more oxygen, but no ATP is formed, and energy is dissipated as heat instead.

The ETC consists of 5 complexes. Complex Ⅰ pumps 4 protons, while Complexes Ⅱ, Ⅲ, and Ⅳ pump 0, 4, and 2 protons, respectively, into the intermembranous space. Complex V uses the proton gradient to phosphorylate ADP → ATP.

questions.text: 40. A 15-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department with complaints of bloody sputum. There was a history of tonsillectomy 1 week back. On examination, the bleeding was from the tonsillar bed. What is the type of hemorrhage in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is having a secondary hemorrhage. It results due to sepsis and premature membranes separation.

Note:

* Reactionary hemorrhage - Occurs within a period of 24 hours.

questions.text: 41. A 57-year-old male presents with massive splenomegaly, pancytopenia, and weight loss. A bone marrow biopsy is performed, revealing "hairy" cells. The findings of flow cytometry analysis are shown below. Which of the following best describes the histopathological changes in the splenic pulp in this patient?

choices.text: Plasma cells in the white pulp
Fried egg leukaemic cells in red pulp

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of hairy cell leukemia in which fried-egg leukemic cells are seen in the red pulp of the spleen.

Hairy cell leukemia is a rare, indolent B-cell lymphoproliferative disorder. A key molecular abnormality is the BRAF V600E mutation, present in >90% of cases, driving MAP kinase signaling and uncontrolled proliferation. Bone marrow infiltration and cytokine production contribute to fibrosis and pancytopenia.

Clinically, patients often present with a gradual onset of symptoms. The hallmark feature is massive splenomegaly, which is usually painless and non-tender. The infiltration of the red pulp often leads to the obliteration of the white pulp and is associated with splenomegaly. The white pulp is usually less involved, though it can show some lymphocytic infiltration.

Peripheral smear shows small lymphoid cells with abundant cytoplasm and characteristic “hairy” projections. Bone marrow aspiration is often a dry tap due to fibrosis, but biopsy reveals a “fried egg appearance” of infiltrating cells. Flow cytometry typically shows positivity for CD11c, CD25, CD103, and CD123

The classic hairy cells are shown below.



The fried egg appearance of the cells is shown below.



Other options:

Option A: A marked increase in the number of plasma cells in the white pulp suggests plasma cell dyscrasia or conditions like multiple myeloma and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), where plasma cells proliferate in response to abnormal antigenic stimulation.

Option B: Expansion of the red pulp with infiltration by abnormal megakaryocytes and myeloid precursors aligns with myeloproliferative disorders like CML or primary myelofibrosis.

Option D: Increased cellularity in the white pulp with a "hairy" appearance of lymphocytes aligns with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) or other lymphoproliferative disorders. However, the term "hairy" should not be confused with hairy cell leukemia here. In CLL, lymphocytes may appear abnormal but do not have distinct cytoplasmic projections, as seen in hairy cell leukemia.

questions.text: 42. Which of the following drugs blocks the binding of gp120 HIV protein to the CCR5 receptor?
questions.solution:
Maraviroc blocks HIV envelope protein gp120 from binding to the CCR5 receptor. 

During the entry of the HIV virus into the host cell, gp120 anchors the virion to the host cell by binding to CD4. Further, gp120 binds to CCR5 chemokine receptors to stabilize the entire complex. Gp41 then mediates the fusion of the viral membrane with the cell membrane of the target cell. Maraviroc is an entry inhibitor that is used for the treatment of HIV. Maraviroc binds to CCR5 receptors and prevents viral entry into the cell. 

Enfuvirtide (option A) is another entry inhibitor that binds to certain domains of gp41 HIV protein and prevents membrane fusion and viral entry into the cell. It is the only antiretroviral drug that is given parenterally (subcutaneous or intravenous). 

Lopinavir (option C) is a protease inhibitor. This class of drugs inhibits the viral protease that is essential for conversion of the inactive protein precursors into functional proteins.

Raltegravir (option D) is an integrase inhibitor. It prevents the formation of covalent bond — and thus the integration — of the HIV DNA and the host cell DNA.

questions.text: 43. A 54-year-old man comes for an evaluation of blood pressure. He had a history of occasional flank pain and a family history of stroke in his father. His BP is 160/90 mm of Hg in both arms. Further evaluation with CT was done and shown below. Which of the following is the most common extrarenal manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation of hypertension, family history of stroke, along with the CT findings showing bilaterally enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts and liver cysts suggests a diagnosis of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). The most common extrarenal manifestation seen in ADPKD is hepatic cysts.

ADPKD is caused by mutations in PKD1 and PKD2 which code for polycystin 1 and 2 respectively. They present incidentally with hypertension, abdominal mass or flank pain. Hematuria can also be present 

The most common extrarenal manifestation is hepatic cysts which are derived from the biliary epithelium. Other extra-renal manifestations of ADPKD:

* Pancreatic cysts

* Berry aneurysms

* Colonic diverticula

* Abdominal hernias

* Mitral valve prolapse 

Management comprises of blood pressure control, antibiotics like trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, quinolones and chloramphenicol for 4-6 weeks, and analgesics. Surgical decompression for cysts may be done.
