questions.text: 44. A young man is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He was driving the car when the accident occurred. On examination, it is noted that the injured leg is shortened. The image of the pelvis radiograph is shown below. Which of the following nerve is most commonly damaged in the given condition?
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows that the femoral head of the left hip is displaced upwards and laterally, and the affected limb is in adduction. Also, the lesser trochanter is obscured. These features indicate posterior dislocation of the left hip joint. The nerve the most commonly injured in this type of dislocation is the sciatic nerve.

Posterior hip dislocation occurs when the knee of the passenger strikes the dashboard. The affected leg is shortened, and lies in an adducted, internally rotated and slightly flexed position.

Imaging shows the following features:

* Upward dislocation of the femoral head

* The size of the femoral head appears smaller compared to the unaffected side

* Adduction of the affected limb.

* The lesser trochanter may not be visible due to the internal rotation of the affected leg

Treatment- A pure hip dislocation should be reduced as early as possible to reduce the risk of osteonecrosis and subsequent osteoarthritis. Important maneuvers to reduce posterior hip dislocation are:

* Rochester method

* East Baltimore lift

* Allis

* Bigelow

* Stimson

Complications of posterior hip dislocation are:

* Injury to the sciatic nerve

* Injury to the superior gluteal artery

* Osteonecrosis of the femoral head

* Secondary osteoarthritis

* Myositis ossificans

* Recurrent instability of the reduced dislocation

questions.text: 45. Identify the organism shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The microscopic image shows typical brush-like conidiophores seen in Penicillium species.

Microscopic appearance of Penicillium spp.:

* The hyphae are hyaline and septate.

* They produce characteristic brush-like conidiophores.

*  The conidiophore is the stalk-like structure, which bears structures known as metulae from which flask-shaped phialides produce chains of asexual spores known as conidia.

Other options:

Option A: Aspergillus spp. has conidiophores with swollen, rounded ends (vesicles), which bear the sterigmata, from which the conidia arise.





Option B: Fusarium spp. on lactophenol cotton blue stain shows small septate hyphae and produces phialides, which give rise to single-celled microconidia or large multi-celled sickle or fusiform-shaped macroconidia, as shown in the image below.



Option D: Scopulariopsis spp. causes onychomycosis, pulmonary infection, fungus ball, and invasive fungal disease in immunocompromised hosts. Microscopically, conidia are large, spherical, lemon-shaped, arranged in chains.

questions.text: 46. A 24-year-old man who went on a skiing trip was hit by an avalanche and was buried in snow. He was rescued after several hours and rushed to the hospital. He appears confused and lethargic with minimal shivering. What is the most probable diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a man with accidental exposure to cold presenting with impaired consciousness and minimal shivering is suggestive of moderate hypothermia.

Hypothermia is defined as core body temperature below 35 °C. Moderate hypothermia (28–32 °C) leads to the failure of thermoregulatory mechanisms, with shivering becoming minimal or absent.

Other features include CNS depression, bradycardia, and reduced cardiac output. Atrial or ventricular arrhythmias and J-wave changes can be seen on an ECG. Respiratory features involve hypoventilation and a loss of protective airway reflexes.

Hypothermia – Stages and Key Findings

Mild hypothermia Moderate hypothermia Severe hypothermia
35–32.2 °C <32.2–28 °C <28 °C
Confusion, apathy, poor judgment, lethargy ↓ Consciousness, EEG abnormalities Coma, absent reflexes, loss of cerebrovascular autoregulation
Tachycardia → bradycardia, 

vasoconstriction; increase in cardiac output and blood pressure

risk of ventricular fibrillation; asystole
Tachypnea Hypoventilation Apnea, pulmonary edema
Shivering present ↓ Shivering, rigidity No motion


Other options:

Option A. Severe hypothermia (<28°C) typically presents with coma, absent reflexes, apnea, and profound cardiovascular collapse, which are not present in this patient.

Option B. Mild hypothermia (32.2–35°C) is marked by alertness with active, vigorous shivering and maladaptive behavior, which is not seen here.

Option C. Cold stress refers to exposure to cold where the core temperature remains above 35°C. The body shows physiological stress responses such as increased metabolism and shivering, but there is no CNS depression or altered consciousness.

questions.text: 47. A 45-year-old patient came with a base of tongue carcinoma. What is the most commonly done procedure to approach the site of carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Lip-split mandibulotomy is the most commonly used access procedure to approach the site of carcinoma at the base of the tongue.

Lip-split mandibulotomy is the most frequently employed access procedure, providing excellent access to the tongue base, posterior oral cavity, and oropharynx. This technique involves creating an osteotomy in the mandible, allowing it to be swung laterally for improved access and manipulation.



Management of oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma (OCSCC) primarily involves surgery, often supplemented with adjuvant radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy. The standard surgical approach is a resection that includes a 1-cm clinical margin around the tumor, without compromising vital structures.  

While many tumors can be removed via a transoral approach, certain tumor sites require an access procedure for safe resection. These include tongue base tumors, large maxillary, posteriorly located tumors, as well as cases in patients who have undergone prior surgery or radiotherapy.

Other options: 

Option B. Weber-Ferguson approach (shown below) is also an access procedure used for extensive tumors invading the floor of the maxillary sinus and can be extended infraorbitally for tumors extending into the orbit.



Option C. Marginal mandibulectomy (rim resection) removes a section of partial mandibular thickness, maintaining its lower border, to achieve sufficient soft-tissue margins when a tumor lies near or invades the mandible.



Option D. Trans-oral approach can be used for oral tumor resection, but safe resection of tongue base tumors and large maxillary tumors is not possible without access procedures such as lip-split mandibulotomy (LSM), the mandibular lingual release, the visor flap, and the Weber–Fergusson approach.

48. Match the following anticoagulants with their specific reversal agents:

1. Heparin a. Idarucizumab
2. Warfarin b. Vitamin K
3. Rivaroxaban c. Protamine sulfate
4. Dabigatran d. Andexanet alfa
questions.solution:
The correct match of specific reversal agents for anticoagulants is depicted in the table below.

1. Heparin c. Protamine sulfate
2. Warfarin b. Vitamin K
3. Rivaroxaban d. Andexanet alfa

Heparin acts by activating antithrombin III, inactivating the active form of clotting factors II, IX, X, XI, XII, and XIII. LMWH, like enoxaparin and dalteparin, are used as first-line anticoagulation therapy in cancer-associated thromboembolism. It is also used to initiate treatment in deep venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. Unfractionated heparin is the anticoagulant of choice in patients with renal failure.

Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist that interferes with vitamin K-dependent clotting proteins like factors II, VII, IX, and X and anticoagulant proteins, proteins C and S. It is used to prevent progression and recurrence in deep venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism after the initial course with low molecular weight heparins (LMWH).

Rivaroxaban is an oral direct factor Xa inhibitor that reduces thrombin generation. It’s given in fixed doses without the need for monitoring and is used for stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation, treatment of DVT/PE, and thromboprophylaxis after knee or hip surgery.

Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor approved for stroke prevention in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation. It is also given as maintenance in acute venous thromboembolism.

questions.text: 49. A renowned artist was started on medication for a chronic ailment. After a couple of weeks, he started painting a series of artworks with a typical yellow predominance shown in the image below. Which of the following drugs can cause yellowing of vision?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of yellowing of vision (xanthopsia). It is an early indication of digoxin toxicity. 

Digoxin is the cardiac glycoside used to treat heart failure and control the ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation/flutter. It inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase, a membrane-bound transporter to increases intracellular sodium. As a result, there is less expulsion of calcium from the cell by the sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX). Increased calcium inside the myocyte leads to an increase in cardiac contractility.

Xanthopsia can also be an adverse effect of thiazide diuretics like chlorthalidone, hydrochlorothiazide, and indapamide.

Other options:

Option A: Ethambutol is an antitubercular drug. It can cause retrobulbar neuritis and red-green color blindness.

Option C: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic drug. It causes corneal verticillata, photosensitivity, blue-gray discoloration that occurs in body areas when exposed to sunlight, hypo or hyperthyroidism, and pulmonary fibrosis.

The image given below shows corneal verticillata. Note the whorl-like corneal pattern of cream-colored lines on the cornea.



Option D: Chloroquine is an antimalarial drug. Adverse effects of chloroquine include headache, blurring of vision, lichenoid skin eruptions, bleaching of hair, and widened QRS interval. High doses may lead to irreversible retinopathy and ototoxicity.

questions.text: 50. The insecticide shown below is used to eliminate the larval form of .............
questions.solution:
The above image shows Paris green which is a commonly used larvicide against Anopheles larvae. Paris green mainly kills larvae who are surface feeders which include Anopheles larvae.

Paris green (Copper acetoarsenite) is an insecticide, which is a green powder that has 50% arsenious oxide. It is a stomach poison and to be effective, it must be ingested by the larvae. 

Other commonly used larvicides are:

* Mineral oils - diesel oil, kerosene, fractions of crude oils, mosquito larvicidal oil

* Synthetic insecticides - Fenthion, Chlorpyrifos, and Abate

Larvicides that are not recommended include organochlorine compounds like DDT and HCH. This is because they have a long residual effect, and contaminate water. Vector mosquitoes may also develop resistance to these compounds.

The larvae of Anopheles lie parallel to the surface of the water. They don't have a siphon tube. In their larval stage, they are surface feeders. In contrast, Culicine larvae like Aedes, Culex, Mansonia have a siphon tube that helps them to suspend in water with their head downwards.

The image below shows Laraval forms of different mosquitoes.

* Environmental control

* This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.

* Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control

* Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.

* Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.

* Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.

* Biological control

* The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.

* These are used in conjunction with other methods.

* Anti-adult measures

* Residual sprays

* Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)

* Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes

* Space sprays

* Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.

* Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.

* Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.

questions.text: 51. A 40-year-old female presents with chronic sinusitis, bilateral pneumonitis, and cavitary lesions on chest X-ray. A renal biopsy reveals necrotising glomerulonephritis. Which of the following antibodies would likely test positive in this patient?

questions.text: 52. A patient having hypopigmented macular lesions and peripheral nerve thickening was diagnosed with leprosy. Which of the following findings is correctly associated with the disease?

choices.text: Lepromatous form shows a subepidermal clear zone
Lepromatous form rarely involves the testis and eyes
Tuberculoid forms feature granulomas and foamy macrophages
Tuberculoid form is the multibacillary form of leprosy

questions.solution:
Lepromatous form shows a subepidermal clear zone is the correct statement about leprosy. 

Leprosy, also known as Hansen's disease, is a slowly progressive infection caused by M. leprae. This bacterium primarily targets the skin and peripheral nerves. Its virulence stems from properties of its cell wall, as it does not secrete toxins. In lepromatous leprosy, the granuloma is typically diffuse and characterized by a subepidermal clear grenz zone, which separates it from the epidermis. 

Lepromatous leprosy, characterized by an abundance of bacteria and thus termed multibacillary, presents with foamy (lipid-laden) macrophages and loose granulomas. In contrast, tuberculoid granulomas are composed of giant cells, epithelioid cells, and lymphocytes.



Other options: 

Option B and C. Lepromatous leprosy affects the skin, peripheral nerves, anterior eye chamber, upper airways, testes, hands, and feet, but it rarely involves the central nervous system and vital organs. It consists of foamy macrophages (lipid-laden) and loose granulomas, while tuberculoid granulomas consist of giant cells, epitheloid cells, and lymphocytes. 

Option D. Tuberculoid leprosy is characterized by a strong host defense, making bacilli rarely detectable, hence known as paucibacillary leprosy. The presence of granulomas and the absence of bacteria are indicative of strong T-cell-mediated immunity. Also, neuronal involvement dominates tuberculoid leprosy.

questions.text: 53. Which is the first structure to be ligated during thyroid surgery?
questions.solution:
The middle thyroid vein is the first structure to be ligated during a thyroid surgery.  

The steps of thyroid surgery are as follows: 

* Patient positioning - head end raised and neck extended

questions.text: 55. A 22-year-old healthy woman presents with recurrent nose and gum bleeding over the past week. Examination reveals non-blanching reddish spots on her neck, chest, and legs. Her platelet count is 24,000/mm³, and a peripheral smear shows decreased platelets with normal morphology. Which of the following is not recommended as a routine therapeutic intervention in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, platelet transfusion is not recommended as a routine therapeutic intervention.

This clinical case with bleeding manifestations in a healthy female with isolated thrombocytopenia suggests a diagnosis of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP).  Platelet transfusion is not recommended as a routine therapeutic intervention.

Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) is an acquired disorder characterised by immune-mediated destruction of platelets and inhibition of platelet release from megakaryocytes. In children, ITP often follows an infection and tends to resolve on its own. In adults, it typically presents as a chronic condition, although some may achieve spontaneous remission.

ITP can be primary or secondary, with common secondary causes including autoimmune diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus, infections such as HIV and hepatitis C, and possibly Helicobacter pylori infection.

ITP is characterised by low platelet counts and mucocutaneous bleeding, including petechiae, bruising, bleeding from the gums, gastrointestinal tract, or heavy menstrual bleeding. In some cases, serious bleeding such as intracranial haemorrhage may occur. Lab test reveals thrombocytopenia. A peripheral blood smear may show normal-large platelets, but other blood cells are normal. Bone marrow biopsy is reserved for cases with atypical features or a lack of response to initial treatment.

Evaluation should include testing for underlying causes, including HIV, hepatitis C, SLE, and immunoglobulin abnormalities. In patients with anemia, a direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test should be done to rule out Evans syndrome.

Patients with platelet counts above 30,000/μL and no significant bleeding generally do not require therapy. When treatment is indicated, such as in cases with platelet counts below 5000/μL or active bleeding, first-line options include corticosteroids like prednisone or dexamethasone and IVIgG. IVIG is especially effective in patients who have had a splenectomy, though it can cause side effects such as aseptic meningitis and kidney injury.

Rituximab, a monoclonal antibody targeting B-cells, can be used in refractory cases. Thrombopoietin receptor agonists, including romiplostim, eltrombopag, and avatrombopag, stimulate platelet production and are effective in chronic ITP. These are now preferred over broad immunosuppressants or splenectomy due to better safety and quality of life outcomes. If splenectomy is planned, patients should receive vaccines against encapsulated organisms such as pneumococcus, meningococcus, and Haemophilus influenzae. 

Platelet transfusions in treating ITP are not effective, as both autologous and allogeneic platelets have reduced survival in this condition, limiting their clinical benefit.

56. During a power cut, vaccines in a PHC ice-lined refrigerator (ILR) were accidentally exposed to room temperature for 18 hours. Which vaccine is most likely to get inactivated first, and what is the maximum safe period of storage in an ILR during a power cut known as?

PHC - Primary health centre
questions.solution:
OPV is the most likely to be inactivated first, and hold-over time is the maximum safe period of storage in an ILR during a power cut.  

Holdover time is the maximum safe storage period for equipment during a power failure. It is the time it takes for the inside cabinet temperature to rise from its temperature at the time of the power cut to the maximum temperature limit of its recommended range. 

OPV is also used as an indicator vaccine for cold chain failure.

Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor the heat exposure of vaccines. It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual color change. If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat, and it must be discarded.

Other options: 

Option B and D. BCG is a freeze-dried vaccine, not heat sensitive, thus at increased temperatures it is inactivated later. Reconstituted BCG vaccine (rBCG) becomes heat sensitive. 

Option C. OPV, being the most heat-sensitive, is inactivated first. The appropriate term for safe storage duration in vaccine management is "hold-over time," not "safe storage time."

questions.text: 57. A 35-year-old man presents with a wrist drop, severe colicky abdominal pain, and constipation. His peripheral smear is shown below. Which of the following is the commonest mode of occupational exposure to the compound responsible?
questions.solution:
The clinical background and the image showing basophilic stippling are suggestive of lead poisoning. Inhalation is the most common route of occupational exposure to lead.

Lead poisoning may occur by:

* Inhalation of fumes and dust of lead

* Ingestion via contaminated hands or when small amounts of lead trapped in the upper respiratory tract are swallowed.

* Absorption through the skin

Painters exposed to lead-based paints usually develop plumbism (lead poisoning). The clinical features of lead poisoning include abdominal colic, constipation, loss of appetite, a blue line on the gums (Burtonian line), basophilic stippling of red cells, anemia, wrist drop, and foot drop. CNS symptoms like insomnia, headache, mental confusion, delirium, may also be seen.

Coproporphyrin levels in urine (CPU) are useful in screening. Measurement of blood and urine lead levels should be done for diagnosis.

Chelation with oral DMSA, calcium EDTA, and dimercaprol are treatment modalities. Correction of iron, calcium, zinc, and calcium deficiencies should be done. Vitamin C is a weak chelating agent.

questions.text: 58. During an acute red eye outbreak, Mr. X presented with right eye irritation and watery discharge. Examination showed conjunctival hyperemia, chemosis, subconjunctival follicles, and tender pre-auricular lymph nodes. Giemsa staining revealed predominant mononuclear cells. What is the diagnosis and causative virus?

choices.text: Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, Coxsackie virus A24

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shipyard eye/epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, most commonly caused by adenovirus serotype 8.  

Epidemic Keratoconjunctivitis/shipyard eye is a serious condition caused by adenovirus serotypes 8 and, less often, by types 19 and 37. It mainly occurs in adults. Mode of spread is contaminated ophthalmic instruments and eye solutions, hand-to-eye contact by medical personnel, or hand-to-eye contact in families and in industries. 

Clinical features include unilateral, acute, follicular conjunctivitis, photophobia, lacrimation, discharge, hyperemia, chemosis, and preauricular lymphadenopathy. After 7 -10 days of conjunctivitis, the infection resolves, and painful, superficial, punctate epithelial opacities appear in the cornea is also characteristic. 

Diagnosis is usually made with clinical symptoms and signs. Conjunctival scrapings are collected, and viral growth characteristic in Giemsa stain shows predominant mononuclear cells in adenovirus etiology, while multinucleated giant cells in herpetic conjunctivitis. 

Treatment includes: 

* Preventive measures such as frequent handwashing, disinfection of ophthalmic instruments, and relative isolation of infected individuals. 

* Supportive treatment such as cold compresses and decongestant eyedrops. 

* If the cornea is involved, topical corticosteroid therapy may be beneficial. 

Other options: 

Option A. Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis caused by Coxsackie virus A24 and Enterovirus 70 usually has a sudden onset with severe eye pain and associated photophobia, blurred vision, lacrimation, erythema, and congestion of the eye. This is typically observed as isolated cases in school-aged children, not as outbreaks. The described age and cytopathic effect exclude this possibility. 

Option B. Herpetic keratoconjunctivitis is usually caused by HSV-1, except in newborns, which is caused by HSV-2, and presents as follicular conjunctivitis, associated with other herpes lesions such as vesicular lesions on the face and eyelids. Preauricular lymphadenopathy is a common co-manifestation. 

Option D. Pharyngoconjunctival fever tends to occur as outbreaks in children's summer camps, causing swimming pool conjunctivitis, and is associated with adenovirus serotypes 3 and 7. Patients present with a clinical triad of conjunctivitis, pharyngitis, and fever. Rarely, keratitis and preauricular lymphadenopathy are seen.

questions.text:
59. Assertion: Unfractionated heparin is safe in patients with kidney disease.
Reason: Unfractionated heparin is metabolized by the liver and excreted via bile.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true and Assertion is explained by Reason
Assertion is true but Reason is false
Both Assertion and Reason are false
Both Assertion and Reason are true and Assertion is not explained by Reason

questions.solution:
Assertion is true but Reason is false.

Unfractionated heparin (UFH) is considered safe in patients with kidney disease because its elimination does not depend heavily on renal function. It is primarily cleared and degraded by the reticuloendothelial system, and only a small fraction of the drug is excreted unchanged in the urine. This means that even in cases of renal impairment, UFH does not accumulate to dangerous levels. Thus, the assertion stating unfractionated heparin is safe in patients with kidney disease is true. 

The reason given in the statement that UFH is metabolized by the liver and excreted via bile is false. The liver and biliary system are not the main pathways for UFH clearance. Instead, the dominant pathway is degradation within the reticuloendothelial system.

questions.text:
60. A 42-year-old woman who is on an MAO inhibitor for major depression for 6 months underwent hernia surgery. Post-operatively the nurse administered an analgesic for the pain. After some time, the patient developed fever, hypotension, rigidity, restlessness, and delirium. Which of the following is unlikely to have caused her symptoms?

MAO: Monoamine oxidase
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of serotonin syndrome. Buprenorphine is unlikely to have caused her symptoms. 

Buprenorphine is a partial μ agonist and an antagonist at δ and κ receptors. It is used as an analgesic and in the management of opioid dependence. It does not have an effect on the neuronal uptake of serotonin, so it is not implicated in causing serotonin syndrome. 

Serotonin is metabolized by monoamine oxidases. MAO inhibitors (MAOIs) inhibit monoamine oxidase enzymes, preventing the breakdown of neurotransmitters such as serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine. When opioids with serotonergic activity are given concurrently with MAOIs, the patient is at risk of serotonin syndrome or MAOI–opioid interaction

Clinical features of serotonin syndrome include:

* Hypotension, flushing

* Extreme agitation, hyperreflexia

* Hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, rigidity

* Delirium, myoclonus, status epilepticus, and death. 

Treatment involves removing the offending agent and supportive care. 

Other options:

Option A. Meperidine (pethidine) is a mu-opioid receptor (MOR) agonist. It has a strong analgesic effect on the central nervous system. It has strong serotonergic activity and is notorious for causing severe reactions in patients on MAO inhibitors.

Option B. Tramadol is a synthetic codeine analog that is a MOR agonist. It is a centrally acting analgesic used in the treatment of mild to moderate pain. It inhibits serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake, giving it the potential to induce serotonin syndrome in patients on MAOIs

Option D. Fentanyl primarily acts as a µ-opioid receptor agonist with minimal serotonergic activity. Fentanyl and sufentanil are commonly used during anesthesia because of their relatively short time of action, cardiovascular safety, and capacity to significantly reduce the dosing requirement for the volatile agents.

questions.text: 61. Which of the following is not a property of enhancers?

choices.text: Functions when located far away from the promoter
Functions only when placed upstream of the promoter
They can bind multiple transcription factors

questions.solution:
Enhancers can function both upstream and downstream from the promoter. Functioning only when placed upstream is a characteristic of promoters, not enhancers.

The properties of enhancers are: 

* Work at varying distances (short or long) from the target promoter 

* Function upstream or downstream of the promoter (Option A)

* Direction/orientation independent (option B)

* Compatible with homologous or heterologous promoters.

* Function by binding one or more proteins (option D)

Other options:

Option A. Enhancers are distance independent- they can work even if located far from the target promoter

Option B. Enhancers are orientation independent, unlike promoters; enhancers can still work if their sequence is flipped. 

Option D. Enhancers typically contain multiple cis-elements and bind proteins like NF-kB, IRF, forming multi-protein complexes.

questions.text: 62. A 4-year-old boy presents with a one-day history of high fever, sudden crampy abdominal pain, and high-volume diarrhea. His mother noted mucus and blood in his stool. A stool sample needs transport to the lab, but a delay is expected. Which transport medium would you use?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of bacillary dysentery, caused by Shigella dysenteriae, for which buffered glycerol saline medium can be used as a transport medium.

Bacillary dysentery caused by Shigella presents with increased abdominal tenderness, tenesmus, and bloody mucus stools, which are treatable with a ciprofloxacin antibiotic course. Buffered glycerol saline medium and Cary-Blair are the two transport media that can be used for Shigella. 

Other options: 

Option B. Amies Medium is used as transport media for Neisseria species, which can cause gonorrhea and meningitis. Stuart's transport medium can also be used for Neisseria. 

Option C. Venkataraman & Ramakrishnan medium is used for Vibrio cholerae. Vibrio cholerae causes cholera, characterized by the sudden onset of painless watery diarrhea that may quickly become voluminous, with rice-like watery stool being a characteristic feature.

Option D. Pike’s medium is used as transport media for Streptococcus pyogenes.

questions.text:
63. A 50-year-old woman presented with complaints of drooping of the angle of the mouth and blurred vision, redness, and pain in both eyes for the past few days. She says that over the past three months she has had a cough, mild fever, and has lost weight. On examination, the right parotid region appears swollen. There is facial asymmetry with drooping of the angle of the mouth, inability to close her right eye, and furrowing of her forehead on the same side. A chest X-ray is performed which reveals the findings attached below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Pulse rate - 84 beats per minute

Blood pressure - 138/76 mm of Hg

Temperature - 99°F
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette along with the chest X-ray finding of bilateral hilar node enlargement is strongly suggestive of Heerfordt-Waldenström syndrome or Uveo-parotid fever. It is a rare presentation of sarcoidosis, and also considered a type of neurosarcoidosis. It is characterized by-

* Fever

* Anterior uveitis- Presents as diffuse congestion of the conjunctival vessels with a prominent circumcorneal injection, pain, and blurred vision

* Parotid gland enlargement- Due to a granulomatous inflammatory reaction. Cervical lymphadenopathy may also be present. 

* Facial nerve palsy- May show epineural granulomas and perineural inflammation involving the facial nerve. 

The bilateral hilar lymph node enlargement further alludes to the diagnosis of sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a systemic disease characterized by the formation of non-caseating granulomas. Patients with sarcoidosis typically present with cough, dyspnea, chest pain, fever, weight loss, arthralgias, and erythema nodosum. Few patients may have neurological involvement with facial nerve palsy being the most common manifestation. 

Diagnosis may be established based on clinical features and biopsy findings. Investigations that are generally used include-

* Chest X-ray:

The chest radiograph is the preferred tool used to stage sarcoidosis. It depends on the lymphadenopathy and pulmonary infiltrates. The parenchymal infiltrates in sarcoidosis are predominantly seen in the upper lobe and appear as diffuse reticular infiltrates. Garland triad is a lymph node enlargement pattern seen on the chest radiographs in sarcoidosis. It involves the right paratracheal nodes, right hilar nodes, and left hilar nodes. It is also known as the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign. 

The staging of sarcoidosis is as below-

Stage 1 Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (usually symmetrical); right paratracheal nodes often enlarged
Stage 2  Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and parenchymal infiltrates
Stage 3 Parenchymal infiltrates without bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
Stage 4 Pulmonary fibrosis  


* Biopsy: Biopsies reveal non-caseating granulomas. 

* Gallium-67 scan:

* Panda sign- It is due to bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands in sarcoidosis, superimposed on the normal uptake in the nasopharyngeal mucosa.

* Lambda sign- It is seen in thoracic sarcoidosis. Bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes are typically involved which can resemble the lambda symbol (λ).

* Elevated serum ACE levels: Granulomas in sarcoidosis are known to produce ACE. 

* Hypercalcemia may be seen, due to increased synthesis of calcitriol – 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D, by alveolar macrophages. In some patients, there may be hypercalciuria, which can lead to nephrocalcinosis.

* Increased CD4/CD8 ratio of these increased lymphocytes in the BAL fluid. A ratio of >3.5 is strongly supportive of sarcoidosis.

* Bronchoscopy shows the typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa.

* Pulmonary function test shows a restrictive lung disease, with impaired gas exchange.

Treatment of Heerfordt-Waldenström syndrome is with corticosteroids, which forms the mainstay of treatment. Immunosuppressants such as mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine, and infliximab can be used in patients who are refractory to steroids. 

The stages of sarcoidosis are given below:



Other options-

Option A: Posner-Schlossmann syndrome, also called glaucomatocyclitic crisis is acute, recurrent, very mild uveitis associated with secondary glaucoma. 

Option C: Lofgren's syndrome is also a form of acute sarcoidosis presenting with erythema nodosum, arthritis, and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: 64. Which of the following plots shows a Lineweaver-Burk plot corresponding to noncompetitive inhibition?
questions.solution:
Image 3 corresponds to a double reciprocal plot (Lineweaver-Burk plot) for non-competitive inhibition.

Non-competitive inhibition occurs when the substrate and the inhibitor are chemically not similar and have different shapes. The inhibitor binds away from the active site, i.e., at the allosteric site. This type of inhibition is known as non-competitive inhibition.

Ex: Pyruvate kinase reaction is inhibited by alanine.

In non-competitive inhibition

* Vmax decreases

* Km remains constant 

In a Lineweaver-Burk plot, the addition of a non-competitive inhibitor causes plots with the same x-intercept (Km is unaffected) but different slopes and y-intercepts.



Although image 4 also corresponds to noncompetitive inhibition, the graph shows a plot of 1/V(Reaction Velocity) vs. concentration of inhibitor across various concentrations of substrate. Hence, it is a Dixon Plot.



* Km is the substrate concentration at which velocity is half of its maximum velocity.

* Vmax is the maximum velocity of a reaction.

Inhibition Km Vmax
Competitive Increases Same
Non Competitive Same Decreases
Uncompetitive Decreases Decreases


 

Competitive inhibition is when the inhibitor binds reversibly to the substrate-binding site and competes with the substrate for the active enzyme binding site. This effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration by which maximum velocity can still be achieved. Therefore, Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the concentration of the substrate required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Therefore, Km is increased in this condition.

The graph shows the changes in Vmax and Km in competitive inhibition.



In uncompetitive inhibition, inhibitors bind with the enzyme-substrate intermediate complex, and inhibit it. This leads to decrease in both Vmax and Km. An example is the inhibition of placental alkaline phosphate (ALP) by phenylalanine.

* Verapamil

questions.text: 66. An elderly woman with strangulated femoral hernia has abdominal pain and fecal vomits. Small intestines were found to be perforated. The next day she underwent a release of hernia and resection of intestines with an end- to-end anastomosis. After that, she started developing signs of peritonitis and died 3 days later. Which of the following options is the most appropriate for line I (a) of the death certificate?
questions.solution:
Line I (a) should contain the immediate cause of death, i.e., the final disease or complication that directly led to death. In this patient, peritonitis developed after intestinal perforation and surgery and was the direct cause of death.

Other options:

Option A. The strangulated femoral hernia, which initiated the pathological sequence, is the underlying cause of death and should be recorded in Line I (c).

Option C. The intestinal perforation is the antecedent cause leading to peritonitis and should be recorded in Line I (b).

Option D. Surgery was a therapeutic intervention, not a cause of death, so it should not be entered in Part I.

67. A 28-year-old man with a history of major depressive disorder is brought to the emergency department after a suicide attempt. He has no prior psychiatric follow-up and has been withdrawn and irritable. Which of the following CSF findings would most likely correlate with his suicidal behaviour?

Homovanillic acid (HVA) 3-methoxy-4-hydroxyphenylglycol (MHPG) Gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA)
questions.solution:
The most likely CSF finding associated with suicidal behavior in major depressive disorder is ↓ 5-HIAA (5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid)

5-HIAA is the primary metabolite of serotonin (5-HT) and serves as an important biochemical marker of serotonergic activity in the central nervous system. It has been shown that low levels of 5-HIAA in CSF are strongly associated with suicidal behavior, impulsivity, aggression, and major depressive disorder. Individuals with reduced serotonergic activity often exhibit poor impulse control and are at greater risk for self-harm or violent suicide attempts.

In contrast, elevated 5-HIAA levels may be observed in individuals with traits like anxiety, obsessionality, or inhibition, rather than suicidal tendencies.

Other options:

Option A. ↑ HVA (Homovanillic acid) is a dopamine metabolite. Alterations may relate to movement disorders or psychosis, but CSF HVA elevation is not a hallmark of suicidality.

Option B. ↑ MHPG (3-methoxy-4-hydroxyphenylglycol) reflects central noradrenergic turnover. Data on depression are inconsistent, and there is no robust association with suicide comparable to low 5-HIAA.

Option C. ↓ GABA deficits have been reported in mood and anxiety disorders, but CSF GABA reduction is not the classic, best-replicated biomarker for suicidal behavior—serotonergic (5-HIAA) findings are stronger.

questions.text: 70. A 36-year-old man, diagnosed with HIV 2 years back, now complains of headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status for the last 3 days. CSF tap was performed, and India ink staining shows the following picture. Which of the following cell components specifically can be used in the diagnosis of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and image suggest a diagnosis of cryptococcus meningitis, in which glucuronoxylomannan (GXM) capsular antigen can be used for diagnosis.

Cryptococcus neoformans infection is more prevalent in patients with HIV/AIDS. The infection is transmitted through the inhalation of aerosolized yeast cells. While the primary pulmonary infection may be asymptomatic and resolve spontaneously, in immunocompromised individuals, the yeast can proliferate and spread, particularly to the central nervous system. This can result in cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, characterized by symptoms such as headache, neck stiffness, and altered sensorium. 

Glucuronoxylomannan (GXM), a capsular antigen, is found in CSF, serum, or urine. It's detectable via enzyme immunoassay or latex slide agglutination and is positive in patients with cryptococcal meningitis. Microscopic examination of India ink-stained CSF reveals prominent, capsulated, budding yeast cells.

Combination therapy of amphotericin B and flucytosine has been considered the standard treatment for cryptococcal meningitis. 

Most fungal cell walls contain chitin, glucans (α-1,3-glucan, β-1,3-glucan, and β-1,6-glucan), and polymers of mannose; thus cannot be used specifically for the diagnosis of Cryptococcus. 

Note - β-1,3-glucan can be detected in CAP organisms, Candida, Aspergillus, and Pneumocystis jeroveci.

questions.text: 71. A 4-year-old boy with autism is receiving behavioural therapy, including structured routines and positive reinforcement to encourage basic sign language. Which of the following best describes the primary goal of behavioural therapy in this child?

choices.text: Improve the IQ of the child

questions.solution:
The primary goal of behavioural therapy in autism is to teach self-care and communication skills through structured learning and reinforcement.

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental condition characterised by the two core features: deficits in social communication and restricted, repetitive patterns of behaviour, interests, or activities. Another feature is language impairment, which occurs early in the developmental period but is not a core feature. Autism is more commonly seen in boys, and symptoms usually start before 3 years of age. 

These disturbances are not better explained by intellectual disability or global developmental delay. Intellectual disability and autism spectrum disorder can frequently co-occur, so to make a comorbid diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder and intellectual disability, social communication should be below that expected for the general developmental level. However, some autistic children have unusual abilities in some areas (e.g., exceptional memory or calculation skills). These are referred to as savant skills.

Management involves behavioural therapy, which focuses on building essential life skills through structured classroom environments, minimal changes in routine, and positive reinforcement. These strategies help children learn basic communication (e.g., through speech or sign language), self-care skills, and interpersonal behaviours like eye contact and imitation. Behavioural techniques are also employed to promote social interaction and reduce problem behaviours like hyperactivity or stereotyped actions.

In addition, psychotherapy—particularly parental counselling and supportive psychotherapy helps in reducing parental guilt and anxiety.

Pharmacotherapy can be used as an adjunct, especially to manage co-occurring symptoms like hyperactivity, aggression, or epilepsy. Drugs such as risperidone and haloperidol have been used to reduce behavioural disturbances. Anticonvulsants are prescribed if the child has associated seizures.

questions.text:
72. Match the following Darrow-Yannet diagrams with the fluid shift occurring in the given conditions.

* Infusion of 3% normal saline

* Infusion of 0.45% normal saline

* Infusion of 0.9% Normal saline

* Normal
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option D. 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a.

Diagram 1 d. Normal
Diagram 2  c. Infusion of 0.9% normal saline
Diagram 3 b. Infusion of 0.45% normal saline
Diagram 4 a. Infusion of 3% normal saline


Darrow-Yannet diagrams depict the change in plasma osmolarity and plasma volume in various conditions. The dotted line in the diagram is the change after either addition or removal of fluid.

Diagram 1 - Normal extracellular fluid (ECF) and intracellular fluid (ICF) balance.

Diagram 2 - The addition of isotonic saline (0.9% normal saline) to ECF does not cause any fluid shift from the ICF. Hence, it only leads to an increase in ECF volume without causing any change in osmolarity.

Diagram 3 - Hypotonic saline (0.45% normal saline) leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ECF. This causes a shift of fluid from the ECF to the ICF until the osmolarity of both compartments become equal. The fluid influx leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ICF as well. Therefore, the net effect is an increase in extracellular volume, increase in intracellular volume, and a fall in osmolarity in both the compartments.

Diagram 4 - The addition of hypertonic saline to ECF pulls the fluid from ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF, and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

questions.text: 73. A 45-year-old man who underwent renal transplantation a year ago presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever with chills, headache, confusion, and vomiting. On cerebrospinal fluid microscopy, gram-positive rods with tumbling motility at 25°C are observed. Which is the most likely mode of transmission of this pathogen?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an immunosuppressed adult with symptoms suggestive of meningitis, and an organism showing tumbling motility at 25°C points to a diagnosis of Listeria monocytogenes. The most likely mode of transmission of Listeria monocytogenes is through the ingestion of contaminated food such as cheese, fruits, or vegetables.

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus that shows characteristic tumbling motility at 25°C and becomes non-motile at 37°C. The image below shows the tumbling motility of Listeria.



Listeria can overcome the food preservation process since it grows at 4°C, with low pH, and high salt concentration. 

It has cell wall surface proteins called internalin A and B that interact with E-cadherin, a receptor on epithelial cells, promoting phagocytosis into the epithelial cells. The virulence factor produced by Listeria is called listeriolysin O. This helps the bacteria to escape and cause septicemia. They are catalase-positive and show beta hemolysis. This helps to differentiate Listeria from other gram-positive bacilli.

Listeriosis can present as gastroenteritis in healthy adults. It usually develops within 48 hours of ingestion of a large inoculum in contaminated food. It can also lead to the formation of an abscess, pharyngitis, pneumonia, and endocarditis. It leads to neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and meningoencephalitis in the elderly and immunocompromised people. Listeriosis in pregnancy can lead to abortion and stillbirth.

Most laboratories do not routinely culture Listeria from stool samples. The diagnosis of systemic listeriosis rests on the isolation of the organism in cultures of blood and spinal fluid.

Ampicillin plus gentamicin is often recommended for therapy. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is the drug of choice for central nervous system infections in patients who are allergic to penicillin. 

Other options:

Option A- Respiratory droplets are the mode of transmission for pathogens, including Neisseria meningitides, respiratory syncytial virus, etc.

Option B- Needlestick injury is the mode of transmission for pathogens, including Hepatitis B, HIV, etc.

Option D- Arthropod bite is the mode of transmission of various pathogens, including dengue virus, yellow fever virus, etc.

questions.text: 74. A very tall and thin young man who is a known case of medullary thyroid cancer is found to have mucosal neuromas. The patient mentioned that his father also had thyroid cancer. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has medullary thyroid cancer, along with mucosal neuromas, and marfanoid habitus, which makes the probable diagnosis as multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2B. 

Multiple endocrine neoplasias are characterized by the presence of tumors in two or more endocrine glands. The variants of MEN are MEN1, MEN2A, MEN2B/3 and MEN4.

MEN 1 is a syndrome complex associated mainly with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors. 

MEN 2A comprises mainly medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenoma. 

MEN 2B/3 consists of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibers, and megacolon.

MEN 4 is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, and reproductive organ tumors.

questions.text:
75. Match the following cell membrane proteins with their function.

1. Synaptobrevin  a. Separation of vesicles from membrane 
2. Synaptotagmin  b. Synaptic vesicle docking and fusion 
3. Dynamin  c. Formation of endocytic vesicle
4. Clathrin  d. Calcium sensor for neurotransmitter release
questions.solution:
The correct match is 

1. Synaptobrevin  b. Synaptic vesicle docking and fusion 
2. Synaptotagmin  d. Calcium sensor for neurotransmitter release
3. Dynamin  a. Separation of vesicles from membrane
4. Clathrin  c. Formation of endocytic vesicle


 

Synaptobrevin is a protein that interacts at the nerve endings to produce synaptic vesicle docking and fusion along with SNAPs, SNAREs. Botulinum toxins target SNARE proteins, thereby disrupting synaptic transmission and highlighting the critical role of these proteins in the process. 

Synaptotagmin is a protein that acts as a calcium sensor for fast synchronous neurotransmitter release. It has two cytoplasmic domains, and the second domain acts as a calcium-binding site. 

Dynamin has guanosine triphosphatase activity and assists in the separation of the endocytic vesicles/pinching off from the membrane. 

Clathrin is associated with receptor-mediated endocytosis, one of the types of endocytosis that allows the uptake of specific molecules into the cell. Molecules bind to the receptors on the surface of the cell. It involves a number of accessory proteins like adaptin, clathrin, and dynamin.

questions.text:
76. A 45-year-old man was scheduled for a lamellar keratoplasty following corneal perforation. He was on IFN-α2b for a unilateral corneal ulcer he developed one year back, which was diagnosed as a Mooren’s ulcer. Which of the following will be positive in this patient?

IFN-α2b - Interferon - alpha 2b
questions.solution:
Patients with a Mooren’s ulcer respond well to IFN-α and may often have a systemic hepatitis C infection. So, positive HCV RNA will be seen in these patients. 

Mooren’s ulcer is a form of chronic, painful, peripheral ulcerative keratitis. It is of two types:

* Benign/Limited type - Unilateral, occurs in the 4th decade of life, more responsive to local treatment

* Virulent - Bilateral, painful, occurs in younger individuals (of African descent), resistant to systemic immunosuppression

Mooren's ulcer occurs in genetically susceptible individuals due to an autoimmune reaction against target molecules in the corneal stroma. Elevated levels of inflammatory cytokines, such as VCAM-1, very late antigen-4, intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1), and lymphocyte function–associated antigen-1, are observed. A Progressive, crescentic corneal ulcer with ‘overhanging‘ edges is seen. Perilimbal involvement is seen in the more aggressive forms.

A step-up treatment approach is followed. Local medical and surgical therapy, followed by systemic medications, are used. Corticosteroids and immunomodulators like cyclosporine, tacrolimus are prescribed.

Other options:

Option A: HIV RNA, associated with HIV retinopathy, CMV retinitis, and anterior segment conditions like uveitis. Optic nerve damage may also be seen.

Option B: HbcAg ocular complications of Hepatitis B include optic neuritis, uveitis. 

Option C: VDRL positive in syphilis. Ocular manifestations include interstitial keratitis, panuveitis, and Argyll Robertson pupil (neurosyphilis).

questions.text: 77. A 2-year-old girl presents with nystagmus in both eyes since 4 months of age. No fixation was noted during the teller acuity test. On fundoscopy, you notice a chalky white disc with sharply defined edges. What is the diagnosis and most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, along with fundoscopy findings, are suggestive of primary optic atrophy that is most likely caused due to craniopharyngioma.

Primary optic atrophy results from direct damage to optic nerve fibers. The disc appears chalky white with clear margins. Causes include tumors (e.g., craniopharyngioma, pituitary adenoma), optic nerve trauma, and hereditary optic neuropathies.

Secondary optic atrophy follows papilledema or optic neuritis, leading to a dirty gray disc with blurred margins due to gliosis. Causes include raised ICP from hydrocephalus, CNS inflammation, or chronic papilledema.

Other options:

Option A. Primary optic atrophy due to hydrocephalus; the association is incorrect. Hydrocephalus generally produces raised intracranial pressure that first manifests as papilledema. If papilledema persists, it later evolves into secondary optic atrophy, not primary.

Option B. Secondary optic atrophy due to craniopharyngioma; the mechanism is mismatched. Craniopharyngiomas are suprasellar tumors that typically compress the optic nerve or chiasma directly. This produces primary optic atrophy, since the axons are damaged without an antecedent papilledema phase.

Option D. Secondary optic atrophy due to hydrocephalus is a known association. Hydrocephalus causes chronic papilledema, which eventually leads to optic nerve pallor. However, in such cases, the optic disc is described as dirty gray with indistinct, blurred margins due to gliosis. This is clearly different from the chalky white, sharply defined disc observed in the child.

questions.text: 78. A patient with a history of renal calculi has been on a low calcium diet for several weeks. On further investigation, which of the following is the most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most likely finding in this patient would be elevated levels of parathormone (PTH).

A diet low in calcium eventually leads to hypocalcemia, which stimulates PTH release. Hence, this patient will have high PTH levels. 

Increased PTH causes:

* Hypophosphatemia due to increased excretion of phosphate via the kidneys.

* PTH acts on the kidneys to increase the absorption of calcium.

* PTH also increases the level of the enzyme 1-α hydroxylase which leads to more production of the active form of Vitamin D- 1,25 dihydrocholecalciferol.

In the presence of hypocalcemia, serum calcitonin levels decrease and the active form of vitamin D increases.



Other options:

Option A. Increased calcitonin levels: Calcitonin lowers serum calcium by inhibiting bone resorption. Its secretion is stimulated by hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia.

Option B. Increased phosphate levels: PTH actually promotes phosphaturia (increased renal phosphate excretion), so phosphate levels decrease rather than rise.

Option D. Activation of 24,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol: This metabolite is an inactive storage form of vitamin D. In hypocalcemia, 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol (active form) is produced, not 24,25.

questions.text: 79. Which pharyngeal arch is the muscle marked below derived from?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the image is the temporalis, and it is derived from the first pharyngeal arch. All muscles of mastication are derived from the first pharyngeal arch.

The first pharyngeal arch is known as the mandibular arch. The artery associated with the first arch is the maxillary artery and the nerve supply is provided by the maxillary and mandibular branches of the trigeminal nerve.

Derivatives of the first pharyngeal arch:

i. Skeletal derivatives: It has 2 prominences:

* Mandibular prominence (ventral)- The mandibular prominence has two components:

* Meckel's cartilage- It forms the malleus, incus, spine of the sphenoid, and the sphenomandibular and anterior malleolar ligaments.

* Mesenchyme surrounding the Meckel's cartilage undergoes membranous ossification to form the mandible.

* Maxillary prominence (dorsal). The mesenchyme of this process forms the maxilla, zygomatic bone, and part of the temporal bone.

ii. Muscular derivatives include

* tensor tympani

* tensor veli palatini

* muscles of mastication (masseter, temporalis, medial pterygoid, lateral pterygoid)

* anterior belly of digastric

* mylohyoid

Pharyngeal pouch derivatives include the auditory tube and the middle ear cavity.

questions.text: 80. An alcoholic patient with cirrhosis is being taken up for surgery. Which of the following induction agents will be the safest to use in this case?
questions.solution:
Sevoflurane is  induction agent of choice in a patient with liver disease.

Hepatic arterial blood flow is reduced in cirrhosis. Sevoflurane and desflurane are known to maintain hepatic blood flow and improve oxygen delivery to the liver. Other factors to avoid that decrease hepatic arterial blood flow are hypotension, high mean airway pressure, and excessive sympathetic activation.

In the case of liver disease, cis-atracurium may be preferred as a neuromuscular blocking agent because the liver does not metabolize it. However, if the patient is unstable with active bleeding, rapid sequence induction can be performed using ketamine/etomidate and succinylcholine.

Other options-

Option (A): Methoxyflurane is a hepatotoxic and highly nephrotoxic drug. Its use gradually declined after the 1970s. 

Option (B): Thiopentone, also known as thiopental, is a barbiturate that is excreted primarily via the liver. Hence, it would lead to toxicity if used in patients with liver disease.

Option (D): Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic agent that accumulates in the liver and undergoes rapid metabolism. It is also known to cause hepatotoxicity, which presents as an elevation in liver enzymes. These two reasons make ketamine unsuitable for use in patients with liver disease.

questions.text: 81. An 18-year-old patient presents to the gynecology department with complaints of amenorrhea. She had no history of cyclical abdominal pain, hormonal intake, radiation or chemotherapy, or any central nervous symptoms like visual disturbances or headaches. After a thorough physical examination, ultrasonography, karyotyping, and diagnostic laparoscopy, the diagnosis of Swyer syndrome was made. Which of the following is not congruent with the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The feature not congruent with Swyer syndrome is normal secretion of AMH. 

In Swyer syndrome, the patient has dysgenetic (streak) gonads that fail to produce Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH). The absence of AMH allows the Müllerian structures (like the uterus) to develop normally, and the lack of testosterone leads to a female external phenotype. Therefore, normal AMH secretion does not occur in this condition.

Swyer's syndrome or pure gonadal dysgenesis occurs as a result of a mutation in the SRY gene or another gene with a testis-determining effect such as DAX1, SF-1, or CBX2. This leads to underdeveloped, dysgenetic gonads that fail to produce androgens or anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH). The following features are seen: 

* Normal prepubertal female phenotype- Absent or poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics due to absence of sex hormones

* Normal Müllerian system development due to the absence of AMH (Uterus and cervix present)

* Female external genitalia

* Presence of dysgenetic testes that cannot produce AMH or sex hormones. They have a risk of malignant transformation

As there is gonadal dysgenesis in a patient with 46 XY karyotype, they are actually determined to be males and are a type of male pseudohermaphrodite. They present with female external genitalia, primary amenorrhea, and absence of secondary sex characters.

Points to be considered while treating these patients:

* Cyclical estrogen and progesterone can induce menstruation

* As they have a normal uterus, pregnancy is possible through in vitro fertilization using a donor egg.

* Streak gonads may undergo malignant transformation and develop into germ cell tumors. Hence, they have to be removed prophylactically.

* Hormonal replacement therapy also has a role in maintaining the bone health of these patients

* Genetic counseling has to be offered to the affected individuals and their family members.

questions.text: 82. A patient diagnosed with multiple sclerosis was prescribed alemtuzumab. The mechanism by which the drug acts, which helps in the treatment of this condition, is_______?

choices.text: Binds with T-cell receptor complex and block antigen recognition.
Binds to CD52 and causes lysis of the cell.
Inhibiting antigen presenting cells by attaching to CD80 and CD86.

questions.solution:
Alemtuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that attaches to CD52 and causes the lysis of B cells, T cells, macrophages, and natural killer cells.

It is used mainly for induction of immunosuppressive therapy in transplant patients and allows the avoidance of the early high dose of steroids. Also used for the treatment of multiple sclerosis and chronic lymphocytic leukaemia.

Other options:

Option A: Muromonab is a monoclonal antibody that attaches to CD3. It binds with the T-cell receptor complex and blocks antigen recognition. It causes internalisation of this T-cell receptor by endocytosis, which prevents proliferative signals from being received by the T cell.

Option C: Daclizumab and Basiliximab prevent IL-2 receptor-mediated T-cell activation. They block IL-2 from binding to activated lymphocytes and are therefore immunosuppressive. They are indicated for prophylaxis of acute organ rejection in renal transplant patients.

Option D: Belatacept acts by inhibiting antigen-presenting cells by attaching to CD80 and CD86. Like Abatacept, it is a fusion protein consisting of the binding segment from CTLA4, which is similar to CD28, and the Fc region of human IgG1. By attaching to CD80/86, CTLA4-Ig prevents the activation of T cells by competitively inhibiting CD28.

questions.text: 84. Identify the true statement regarding the marked structure in the given image of the axilla.

choices.text: It enters the forearm between the 2 heads of supinator
It lies medial to the third part of axillary artery in the axilla
It provides sensory innervation to lateral one and half fingers
It enters the forearm between the 2 heads of pronator teres

questions.solution:
The marked structure is the median nerve, and the true statement regarding the median nerve is option D, i.e., it enters the forearm between the 2 heads of the pronator teres.

The median nerve is formed by the joining of the lateral root (C5, C6, C7) from the lateral cord and the medial root (C8, T1) from the medial cord. It lies lateral to the third part of the axillary artery in the axilla and runs down to the arm. It shifts from the lateral to the medial side and stays medial to the brachial artery in the cubital fossa.

It enters the forearm between the 2 heads of the pronator teres. It lies lateral to the ulnar artery and descends through the forearm posteriorly and is adherent to the flexor digitorum superficialis and anterior flexor digitorum profundus. Just before the wrist, it lies between the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor carpi radialis. It then passes deep to the flexor retinaculum into the palm.

The median nerve does not give any branches in the axilla and the arm.



Branches in the forearm:

* Nerve to pronator teres

* Nerve to palmaris longus, flexor carpi radialis and flexor digitorum superficialis

* Anterior interosseous nerve supplying flexor pollicis longus, lateral part of flexor digitorum profundus, and pronator quadratus

* Palmar cutaneous branch supplying the thenar skin

Branches in the hand:

* Digital cutaneous branch supplying the lateral three and a half fingers

* Muscular branches to thenar muscles (except adductor pollicis), 1st and 2nd lumbricals

Other options:

Option A- Posterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the radial nerve passes between the 2 heads of the supinator.

Option B- Ulnar nerve lies medial to the third part of the axillary artery in the axilla.

Option C- Median nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral three and a half fingers.

questions.text: 85. During intense exercise, a graph illustrates the shifts in ventilation. It's observed that the changes in alveolar and arterial CO2 are barely noticeable. What accounts for this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The levels of arterial and alveolar CO2 remain relatively constant during exercise is explained by the isocapnic phenomenon. 

Vigorous exercise leads to increased lactic acid production. The buffering of this acid releases more CO2, which in turn boosts ventilation. Despite the heightened acid production, the rise in ventilation and CO2 production remains proportional. This ensures that alveolar and arterial CO2 levels remain relatively stable; this process is known as isocapnic buffering.

Pulmonary ventilation rises proportionally with exercise intensity. The initial surge in respiratory rate is due to psychological factors and signals from proprioceptors in muscles, tendons, and joints. During exercise, arterial pH, pCO2, and pO2 generally remain stable. Respiration is further stimulated by elevated potassium (K+) levels activating peripheral chemoreceptors, increased body temperature, and heightened neuron sensitivity to CO2.

At rest, oxygen uptake is around 250 mL/min, but this can escalate to 4000 mL/min during strenuous exercise. The lungs' oxygen diffusion capacity also improves. Initially, the body prioritizes using stored oxygen rather than immediately increasing oxygen intake to fuel working muscles.

Other options:

Options B and C. The amount of oxygen required after muscle contraction for its oxygen replenishment is known as oxygen debt. The oxygen required for the restoration of phosphocreatine is known as alactacid oxygen debt, while that required for lactic acid removal is known as lactic acid oxygen debt.

Option D. Phosphocreatine-creatine system combined amounts of cell ATP and cell phosphocreatine provide energy are used during endurance as sources of energy. These substances together can provide maximal muscle power for 8 to 10 seconds.

questions.text: 86. Adult T-cell leukemia caused by HTLV-1 contributes to oncogenesis through which of the following oncoproteins?
questions.solution:
Adult T-cell leukemia caused by HTLV-1 contributes to oncogenesis by Tax and HBZ oncoproteins.

Tax and HBZ  are two viral proteins that alter the transcription of host cell genes and interact with certain host cell signaling proteins, and contribute to leukemogenesis through uncertain mechanisms in Human T-Cell Leukemia Virus Type 1 (HTLV-1).

Other options:

Option B. E6 and E7 are responsible for oncogenesis in the human papillomavirus. E6 and E7, which bind to p53 and Rb, respectively, with high affinity and neutralize their function.

Option C. The CagA (cytotoxin-associated A) gene is responsible for the pathogenicity of H. pylori.

Option D. EBNA-2 is the Epstein-Barr virus gene, which, along with several other factors, triggers B-cell signaling pathways and induces B-cell growth and transformation.

questions.text: 87. A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination, foul-smelling discharge and yellowish-green crusts are present in the nasal cavity. Which of the following composition of alkaline solution (per 280ml of water) can be used in this patient to remove the crusts?

choices.text: Soda bicarbonate 2 part, Sodium biborate 1 part, Calcium chloride 2 parts
Soda bicarbonate 1 part, Sodium biborate 1 part, Sodium chloride 2 parts
Calcium bicarbonate 1 part, Sodium biborate 2 part, Sodium chloride 2 parts
Magnesium bicarbonate 1 part, Sodium biborate 2 part, Potassium chloride 2 parts

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of anosmia, foul-smelling discharge, and yellowish-green crusts in the nasal cavity points to a diagnosis of atrophic rhinitis.

The composition of alkaline solution is soda bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, and sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water.

It is used to irrigate the nasal cavities. It loosens the crusts and helps in its removal.

Other treatment options:

* 25% glucose in glycerine

* Estradiol spray

* Submucosal placental extract

* Local antibiotics

* Potassium iodide

* Systemic use of streptomycin

Pearl PM1275: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

* Symptoms:

* Foul smell from the nose

* Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity

* Epistaxis on removing of the crusts

* Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).

* Signs:

* Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum

* After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates

* Nasal mucosa appears pale.

questions.text: 88. A child presents with palpable purpura, abdominal pain, and pain in the knee joint resulting from arthralgia. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. Which of the following finding is most likely present in the patient?

choices.text: IgA deposition in the mesangial region

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the investigations are suggestive of Henoch-Schönlein purpura. IgA deposition in the mesangial region is most likely finding to be present in this patient.

Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a subtype of acute leukocytoclastic vasculitis that is seen more commonly in children and adolescents following an upper respiratory infection. The patient may present with the following clinical features:

* Skin lesions- characteristically involve the extensor surfaces of arms and legs, and also the buttocks

* Abdominal manifestations- include pain, vomiting, and intestinal bleeding

* Arthralgias- primarily of the knees and ankles

* Renal manifestations- include gross or microscopic hematuria, nephritic syndrome, or nephrotic syndrome. Renal manifestations are more severe in adults. A rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis is seen in some cases.

Microscopic findings:

* IgA deposition in the mesangial region is the pathognomic feature. Sometimes there is the deposition of IgG and C3 along with IgA.

* Renal lesions show focal or diffuse mesangial proliferation, and/or endocapillary proliferation to crescentic glomerulonephritis.

* Skin lesions show subepidermal hemorrhages and necrotizing vasculitis of small vessels. Direct immunofluorescence examination shows deposits of IgA within dermal blood vessel walls.

Other options:

Option A: Alport syndrome is caused by mutations that affect type IV collagen that result in hematuria with progression to chronic renal failure. It is accompanied by nerve deafness and various eye disorders, including lens dislocation, posterior cataracts, and corneal dystrophy.

Option B: Microscopic polyangiitis is a necrotizing vasculitis that affects capillaries, small arterioles, and venules. Most cases are associated with MPO-ANCA. The features include hemoptysis, hematuria, and proteinuria, bowel pain or bleeding, muscle pain or weakness, and palpable cutaneous purpura.

Option C: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) occurs due to antibody-mediated destruction of platelets. Autoantibodies, most often directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb–IIIa or Ib–IX are found. The patient can present with petechiae, ecchymoses, easy bruising, nosebleeds, and gingival bleeding. The disease manifests first with melena, hematuria, or excessive menstrual flow.

questions.text: 89. Identify the incision marked in the image.
questions.solution:
The incision shown in the image is a modified Blair's incision done for parotidectomy. 

The modified Blair incision/modified lazy S incision comprises three distinct parts:

* The horizontal segment runs along the skin crease, positioned two finger breadths from the angle of the mandible.

* The vertical segment is situated near the tragus, within a skin crease if one is present.

* The communicating segment forms a gentle curve, connecting the horizontal and vertical components.

Facelift incisions and retroauricular incisions are other incisions used in parotidectomy.



Types of parotidectomy: 

* Extracapsular dissection

* Superficial parotidectomy

* Adequate parotidectomy

* Total conservative parotidectomy

* Radical parotidectomy

Complications of parotidectomy: 

* Frey's syndrome

* Facial nerve weakness

* Sialocele

* Transsection of the great auricular nerve.

* Infection

Option D. Weber-Ferguson incision (shown below) is used for extensive tumors of the oral cavity invading the floor of the maxillary sinus.

questions.text: 90. The radiologist performs myocardial perfusion imaging with technetium-99m labeled compounds in a cardiac patient to determine the effectiveness of acute revascularization. Identify the true statement about technetium-99m.

choices.text: Pure beta emitter with half life of 12 hours
Pure gamma emitter with half life of 12 hours
Pure beta emitter with half life of 6 hours
Pure gamma emitter with half life of 6 hours

questions.solution:
Technetium-99m is a pure gamma emitter, as it is in the metastable state, and its half-life is  6 hours.

Technetium agents based on the Technetium-99m (Tc-99m) radioisotope are the most frequently used agents in medical imaging. The radioactive technetium can be chelated to several different compounds to create specific radiopharmaceuticals and optimize imaging of various structures.

Half-life of Tc 99m is 6 hours and produces gamma rays of 140 keV.

Myocardial perfusion imaging is done with either thallium-201 or technetium-99m labeled compounds (e.g., technetium-99m sestamibi).

questions.text: 91. The CT of a patient with a vertebral hemangioma would demonstrate _______.

choices.text: Corduroy sign in the axial section and Polka dot sign in the sagittal section
Corduroy sign in the sagittal section and Polka dot sign in the axial section
Both Corduroy sign and Polka dot sign in the sagittal section
Both Corduroy sign and Polka dot sign in the axial section

questions.solution:
In patients with vertebral hemangioma, corduroy sign is seen in the sagittal and coronal section and polka dot sign is seen in the axial section of CT scans.

Hemangioma is typically a benign tumor of the vertebral body. This tumor is mostly clinically silent and is usually detected incidentally. The vertebral body is the most common location for hemangioma. Atypical location of hemangioma is the posterior elements of the vertebra and is indicative of an aggressive lesion. Symptomatic hemangiomas usually present with pain, neurologic compromise, or fractures.

Radiographs show large lesions with vertical striations and coarse, thick trabeculae, giving a corduroy appearance in sagittal and coronal sections. It is also known as the jail bar sign.

On an axial computed tomography (CT) scan, hemangioma shows a classic polka dot appearance. MRI is the standard for diagnosing hemangiomas.

Treatment: Most hemangiomas do not require treatment. Vertebroplasty is useful in aggressive hemangiomas. 

The below CT image shows characteristic polka dot appearance (left) and corduroy appearance (right):



The name corduroy comes from the similarity to the corduroy cloth (seen in the image below) in appearance.

questions.text: 92. A primigravida comes to the primary health center for a routine antenatal visit and enquires about consumption of iron tablets. Which of the following is recommended for pregnant women during the antenatal period based on Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme?

choices.text: 100 mg of elemental iron for 100 days
60 mg of elemental iron for 100 days
60 mg of elemental iron for 180 days
100 mg of elemental iron for 180 days

questions.solution:
According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme, 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid are given daily for a minimum of 180 days. It is to be started from the fourth month of pregnancy and to be continued for 180 days, post-partum.

Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme (2018) is an initiative that aims to strengthen the existing mechanisms and foster newer strategies for tackling anemia. It follows a 6x6x6 strategy. Here, 6 groups of beneficiaries are assisted by 6 interventions and 6 institutional mechanisms.

The six distinct groups of beneficiaries are children of 6-59 months of age, children of 5-9 years, adolescents, women in the reproductive age group, pregnant women, and lactating mothers. 

The six interventions are:

* Iron and folic acid supplementation prophylactically

* Deworming

* Behavior change communication campaign

* Using digital methods and point-of-care treatment

* Provision of iron and folic acid fortified foods

* Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia

questions.text: 93. A diabetic patient was diagnosed to have malignant otitis externa. Which of the following is not a characteristic of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the causative organism of malignant otitis externa, which affects elderly uncontrolled diabetics and immunocompromised individuals. P. aeruginosa is non-lactose fermenting in nature.

P. aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacillus which is:

* an obligate aerobe (Option A)

* catalase-positive (Option B)

* oxidase-positive

* non-lactose fermenting

* shows characteristic swarming motility.

They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin (Option D) and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (red), pyomelanin (brown). This is responsible for the formation of blue-green pus in infections and also its appearance on culture media.  It exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer. It is notorious for being resistant to antimicrobials and antiseptics and hence is a frequent contaminant in hospital samples and cause for many hospital acquired infections. 

Diseases caused by P. aeruginosa include:

* Burns infections (most common cause)

* Shanghai fever: severe enteric disease and sepsis

* Malignant otitis externa in diabetics

* Jacuzzi syndrome (Hot tub folliculitis)

* Ecthyma gangrenosum

* Green-nail syndrome

The images below show green-colored colonies of Pseudomonas aeruginosa on nutrient agar, and the characteristic swarming motility.
