questions.text:
173. A primi mother delivered a neonate through NVD. Her past medical records reveal that she had seizures and was under valproate which she discontinued during pregnancy and restarted due to a seizure episode during the second trimester. She is concerned about breastfeeding what would be your advice?

NVD - Normal vaginal delivery

choices.text: Reassure her that antiepileptics don’t cross into breastmilk
Since valproate is hepatotoxic, avoid it and continue breastfeeding
Continue taking the antiepileptic and breastfeeding
Prefer formula milk as antiepileptics potentially cross into breastmilk

questions.solution:
Antiepileptics can be continued in the postpartum period and alongside breastfeeding. 

Maternal drug intake during nursing may have adverse effects on lactation and the baby through the ingested milk. Any drug ingested by a nursing mother may be present in her breast milk however, the levels are usually low when compared to those in the mother and such low levels are usually not of any clinical significance to the infant. 

The milk concentrations of some drugs like iodide may exceed those in the maternal plasma. However, the benefits of breastfeeding stand out. The risk of drug exposure to the neonate must be weighed against these benefits. 

Antiepileptics do cross into breastmilk, but the benefits of breastfeeding exceed the risks of exposure to antiepileptics, and hence breast milk supersedes other options like discontinuing the drug or usage of formula milk.

questions.text: 174. In terms of India’s demographic transition, a rising literacy rate is most likely associated with which stage?
questions.solution:
A rising literacy rate is most likely associated with the late expanding stage of India's demographic transition, where the death rate has already declined, and the birth rate starts to fall.

A rising literacy rate, particularly among women, is one of the key drivers of fertility decline. It leads to delayed marriage, reduced family size, increased contraceptive use, and greater health-seeking behavior. Other options:

Option A. High stationary - Both birth and death rates are high; literacy is generally low, and fertility remains unaffected. Seen in pre-industrial societies.

Option B. Early expanding – Death rate declines, but birth rate remains high due to lack of female education and low contraceptive use. Population growth is rapid.

Option D. Low stationary – Both birth and death rates are low. This is seen in developed countries where literacy is high, but India has not yet reached this stage.

Pearl PM1694: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

* Stage 1 - High stationary 

* High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary

* Narrow demographic gap

* Stage 2 - Early expanding 

* The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged

* The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum

* Stage 3 - Late expanding

* Death rate declines further and birth rate falls

* India is in this stage, currently

* The demographic gap starts declining

* Stage 4 - Low stationary 

* Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary

* Narrow demographic gap

* Stage 5 - Declining 

* The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate

* The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: 175. A 57-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of shortness of breath and dyspnoea at night. There is no history of bronchial asthma. Investigations revealed the presence of pulmonary venous hypertension. Which of the following is the earliest radiographic finding seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The earliest radiological finding in pulmonary venous hypertension is the enlargement of the upper zone vessels.

Pulmonary venous hypertension:

It is seen in conditions with impaired left ventricular function. Any left-sided pathology that impaired the forward flow of blood from the heart will cause a rise in left atrial pressure. This increase in pressure is transmitted from the atria to the pulmonary veins producing pulmonary venous hypertension.

Radiological findings in pulmonary venous hypertension:

* Enlargement of upper zone blood vessels - the first radiological finding seen

* Mild haziness in the lower zone with attenuation of lower zone vessels

* Loss of definition of heart and mediastinal contours - This occurs as the normal sharp interface is obscured by the extravascular fluid

* Kerley B lines- Horizontal subpleural lines, 1 cm in length and 1-3 mm in thickness, usually seen at the costophrenic angle. They indicate interstitial edema

* Thickening of the interlobar fissure due to interstitial edema

* Pulmonary effusions that are large and bilateral may be also seen

* Long-standing cases can produce two additional findings:

* Hemosiderosis: fine punctate calcifications scattered throughout the lung

* Pulmonary ossific nodules: Small areas of bone formation in the lung seen in long-standing severe cases.

questions.text: 176. A 62-year-old woman presents with sudden onset dysarthria and impaired sensation over the right side of her face. Further examination shows loss of pain and temperature on the left side of the body. When asked to walk in a straight line, she sways to the right side. Which of the following marked vessels is most likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral medullary syndrome/Wallenberg syndrome. This may result from a stroke affecting the ipsilateral (right-sided, in this case) vertebral artery marked as '4' in the image above.



Lateral medullary syndrome: The clinical findings correspond to the neuroanatomical structures affected in the lateral portion of the medulla:

* Descending tract and nucleus of CN V (trigeminal)- loss of pain and sensation over the ipsilateral half of the face.

* Inferior cerebellar peduncle – ipsilateral ataxia (gait and limb)

* Lateral spinothalamic tract – loss of pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body.

* IX and X CN - ipsilateral paralysis of the palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex giving rise to dysphagia and dysarthria.

* Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea

* Descending sympathetic tract—ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis).

The lateral medullary syndrome may also occur as a consequence of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) stroke. PICA is a branch of the vertebral artery.



Other options:

Option A. Middle cerebral artery is the structure marked as 2 in the image. It supplies the lateral surface of the cerebral hemispheres. Occlusion causes contralateral face and arm weakness, contralateral hemisensory loss, aphasia (if dominant hemisphere), or hemineglect (if nondominant hemisphere)

Option C. Anterior cerebral artery is marked as 1. It supplies the medial surface of the frontal and parietal lobes. Infarction produces contralateral lower limb weakness, urinary incontinence, and sometimes personality changes. Does not produce cranial nerve palsies or crossed sensory findings.

Option D. Basilar artery is marked as 3 in the image. It supplies the pons and midbrain. Occlusion can cause locked-in syndrome (quadriplegia with preserved consciousness, with only vertical eye movements spared) or lateral pontine syndromes. The clinical picture would involve corticospinal tract signs, gaze palsy, or facial weakness, not lateral medullary findings.

questions.text: 177. A 6-week-old infant is brought to the OPD for immunization. The mother is HIV-positive and has been on lifelong ART since before pregnancy. The infant received nevirapine prophylaxis after birth and is exclusively breastfed. HIV-1 PCR results from a dried blood spot at 6 weeks are reported as negative. Which of the following is recommended for this child?

choices.text: Repeat HIV-1 PCR with whole blood sample immediately

questions.solution:
The mother was on lifelong ART during pregnancy, and the infant received only nevirapine prophylaxis, making this a low-risk case. In a low-risk HIV-exposed infant, nevirapine prophylaxis is given only for the first 6 weeks, after which it is stopped, and co-trimoxazole prophylaxis must be started to prevent Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia.

Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis at 6 weeks of age is recommended in all HIV-exposed infants, irrespective of an early negative PCR. This is because the infant is still at risk of acquiring HIV through breastfeeding, and a single negative HIV PCR at 6 weeks does not rule out later transmission. 

Cotrimoxazole is given daily from 6 weeks of age until HIV infection is definitively excluded, which is usually after cessation of breastfeeding and confirmatory testing at 18 months. 

The following flowchart illustrates the algorithm for diagnosing and managing HIV infection in infants.



Other options:

Option A: Stopping nevirapine and starting zidovudine is not recommended as ongoing prophylaxis for HIV-exposed infants. NACO PPTCT guidelines specify daily nevirapine from birth until 6 weeks, irrespective of feeding type. After 6 weeks, the recommended prophylaxis is cotrimoxazole, not zidovudine.

Option C. Repeat HIV-1 PCR with a whole blood sample, is not done immediately at 6 weeks if a negative report with a dried blood sample is already obtained. A single negative HIV PCR at 6 weeks does not rule out infection due to risk from breastfeeding. However, the guideline-directed next step is cotrimoxazole prophylaxis, not immediate retesting. Repeat PCRs are done at 6 months, 12 months, and 18 months or at cessation of breastfeeding

Option D: Continuing nevirapine therapy till 6 months of age is not recommended in the guidelines. Nevirapine is continued from birth until 6 weeks of age, irrespective of feeding.

Pearl PM2199: Prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT)

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

* HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.

* Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.

* Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers

* Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)

* Exclusive breastfeeding counseling

* Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby

* Initiation of ARV in babies:

* Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age

* High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)

* Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women

* Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines

questions.text:
178. Which of the following cancers are included under the population-based screening component of NP-NCD?

* Oral cancer

* Cervical cancer

* Esophageal cancer

* Breast cancer

* Lung cancer
questions.solution:
Under the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Non-Communicable Diseases (NP-NCD), the population-based screening component focuses on common and preventable cancers in India, namely:

* Oral cancer – via oral visual examination (OVE)

* Breast cancer – via clinical breast examination (CBE)

* Cervical cancer – via VIA (Visual Inspection with Acetic acid)

These screenings are targeted at men and women aged 30 years and above, and  are primarily conducted by ASHAs and ANMs at the community level.

These cancers were selected due to their high burden in India, the availability of low-cost screening tools, and the possibility of early detection at the primary care level.

Cancers not included in population-based screening:

Esophageal cancer – Lacks a feasible, non-invasive screening method for primary care settings. Not part of the NPCDCS screening protocol.

Lung cancer – Although prevalent, there is no low-cost, validated population screening tool available. Focus remains on tobacco cessation and prevention rather than screening.

questions.text: 179. In the SRK formula for intraocular lens power calculation 'E=A-2.5L-0.9K', the value of L is estimated using__________
questions.solution:
The value of L, which is the axial length of the eyeball is calculated using the A-scan ultrasonographic biometry

 The most widely used formula for intraocular lens power calculation is the Sanders-Retzlaff-Kraff formula, given by

 E = A - 2.5L - 0.9K

Where E is the emmetropic power designated for the eye 

* A is a constant which is specific for each lens type.

* L is the axial length of eyeball in mm determined using the "A" scan ultrasonography.

* K is the average corneal curvature, which is determined by keratometry.

questions.text: 180. A screening test gave positive results in 60% of the diseased individuals and 20% of the healthy individuals. Calculate the Specificity for this test.
questions.solution:
The specificity of a test from the given information can be calculated as 0.8.

60% of individuals having the disease came out to be positive. So for 100 diseased individuals, 60 are True positives and 40 are False negatives.

20% of the individuals not having the disease came out to be positive. so for 100 healthy individuals, 20 are False positives and 80 are true negatives.

The specificity of a test is given by those who are healthy (do not have the disease) and test negative (true negatives) out of the total healthy population. So the specificity = TN divided by TN+FP, i.e 80/100 = 0.8

The sensitivity of a test is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives) out of the total diseased population. Here Sensitivity = TP/TP+FN = 60/100 = 0.6

The test's positive predictive value is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives) out of the total positive population. Here PPV = TP/TP+FP = 60/80 = 0.75

The negative predictive value of the test is given by those who do not have the disease and test negative (true negatives) out of the total negative population. NPV here = TN/TN+FN = 80/120 = 0.67



Pearl PM0358: Validity of a Screening Test

* Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.

* It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.

* These are the inherent properties of a screening test.

* PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.

* Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.



Formulae

TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN


* PPV varies directly with prevalence

* NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text:
181. A 60-year-old woman with a history of hypermature cataract now presents with a sudden onset of eye pain and headache. Examination shows a congested and edematous conjunctiva, angles of the anterior chamber blocked with elevated IOP. Which of the following could be the causes of the present condition?

IOP - Intraocular pressure
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of phacotopic glaucoma due to subluxation of the lens. 

An anterior dislocation or subluxation of the lens causes phacotopic glaucoma, a type of lens-induced secondary angle closure glaucoma. A partial subluxation compresses a large segment of the anterior chamber, while a complete dislocation into the anterior chamber causes complete blockage of the iridocorneal angle.

Its clinical features are similar to acute angle closure glaucoma, such as sudden onset of pain, chemosis, and edematous conjunctiva and cornea with sudden raised IOP, and is associated with a history of hypermature cataract.



Other options:

Option A: Opacification of the lens is a cataractous change seen in age-related degeneration, diabetes, secondary cataract, and congenital cataract. 

Option B. In phacomorphic glaucoma, there is swelling of the lens due to cataractous changes or traumatic rupture of its capsule, which obliterates the angle and presents with features of acute angle closure glaucoma. 

Option D. Rupture of the lens causes lens proteins to be released into the aqueous, known as phacolytic glaucoma, a secondary open-angle glaucoma. Phagocytes engulf the lens particles and are deposited at the trabecular meshwork, obstructing the drainage and causing glaucoma. It can also be associated with a history of hypermature cataract.

questions.text: 182. A 60-year-old male patient presented with frequently changing bowel habits. He noticed blood in the stools which were not associated with pain. There was no history of weight loss. Barium enema was done and the image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the barium enema image is suggestive of colonic diverticulosis.

Diverticulosis refers to the condition where multiple outpouchings occur along the gastrointestinal tract, resembling a saw tooth. Colonic diverticulosis is more common among the aged group of more than 50 years. Colonic diverticulosis is primarily false diverticula, as only the mucosa and muscularis mucosa have herniated. Due to the high intraluminal pressure, they are referred to as the pulsion type of diverticula.

A low fibre diet results in smaller stool volume, which increases intraluminal pressure for propulsion. The higher pressures get directed to the colonic wall, resulting in pulsion diverticula. The sigmoid colon is the most common location.

The majority of patients with diverticulosis are usually asymptomatic. However, some patients may present with abdominal cramps, altered bowel habits, and painless rectal bleeding. Diverticulosis can present with complications like:

* Diverticulitis

* Abscess

* Peritonitis

* Intestinal obstruction

* Hemorrhage 

* Fistula formation

The diagnosis is confirmed by a colonoscopy or an X-ray barium enema. Barium enema radiograph shows multiple barium-coated outpouchings from the colonic wall and gives the appearance of a saw-tooth. In cases of severe abdominal pain, a CT scan is preferred to avoid the risk of intestinal perforation.

A high fibre diet reduces the incidence of diverticulosis. Antispasmodics can be prescribed to reduce intestinal spasms. Most cases of bleeding are self-limiting. If persistent bleeding is present, surgical, endoscopic, or radiological interventions can be done to reduce the bleeding.

Other options:

Option B- Carcinoma colon shows apple-core sign on barium enema as shown below.



Option C- Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that shows the string sign of Kantor on barium enema as shown below.



Option D- Intussusception shows the coiled-spring appearance on barium enema as shown below.

The image below is a barium swallow showing eosinophilic esophagitis and associated stricture:



Barium meal: Used to assess stomach and duodenum. (95% BaSO4 is used)



Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used)



Barium enema: Used to assess the large intestine (25% BaSO4 is used)

questions.text: 183. A patient presents in a deeply unresponsive state with a GCS of 3, with no suspected signs of trauma and no available history. What drug intervention would you give?
questions.solution:
Glucose, thiamine and naloxone should be given in this condition.

When a patient presents in a deeply unresponsive state with a GCS of 3, the immediate goal is to stabilise vital functions and rapidly correct reversible causes of coma. Coma can result from diffuse dysfunction of the cerebral hemispheres or reduced activity of the brainstem reticular activating system, and in the absence of history, empirical treatment is necessary.

The first priorities are to secure the airway, ensure adequate ventilation and circulation, and then address potential metabolic or toxic causes. Administration of thiamine, glucose, and naloxone is recommended when the etiology of coma is not immediately clear. Glucose treats hypoglycemia, a common and reversible cause of coma. Thiamine is given before or with glucose to prevent Wernicke’s encephalopathy, especially in malnourished or alcohol-dependent patients. Naloxone and dextrose are administered if there is an opioid overdose. Since a clear history is not available, it is beneficial to administer Naloxone.

questions.text: 184. A patient presents with a 4-day history of gritty sensation, itchiness, multiple follicles, and conjunctival erythema in the left eye post-uveitis drug treatment. What else can this drug be used for?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of toxic follicular conjunctivitis. Atropine, used in treating uveitis, is known to cause this condition and may also be utilized for acute bradyarrhythmia. 

Toxic follicular conjunctivitis is characterized by a gritty sensation, itchiness, multiple follicles, and conjunctival erythema. A patient with a history of uveitis may require symptomatic treatment with atropine, which can induce toxic follicular conjunctivitis.

It follows chronic exposure of the conjunctiva to a variety of foreign substances, including molluscum of the lid margin, infection of the lash by pthriasis pubis, use of eye cosmetics, and prolonged use of eye medications.

Medications such as atropine, neomycin, idoxuridine, gentamicin, and epinephrine can cause toxic follicular conjunctivitis. These drugs incite type IV delayed Hypersensitivity reaction with periocular erythema and follicular conjunctivitis.

Atropine is a competitive antimuscarinic receptor antagonist used in various conditions, including preanesthetic medication to reduce secretions, symptomatic bradycardia, and organophosphate poisoning.

Angle closure glaucoma, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and tachyarrythmia are contraindications for the use of atropine, complicating these conditions further.

questions.text: 185. An orthopedic resident prescribes pain relievers for a patient diagnosed with Kohler's disease. Which of the following bones is usually affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
Osteochondritis of the navicular bone is known as Kohler's disease.

Osteochondrosis and osteochondritis are conditions in which a small segment of articular bone or cartilage is demarcated or separated and necrosed. The affected part shows features of ischemic necrosis. This is widely seen in adolescents and young adults, with trauma and repetitive stress being the common causes. An example of this disorder is osteochondritis dissecans.

Commonly affected sites are slightly bulbous areas with convex articular surfaces: 

* Inner (medial) surface of the medial femoral condyle in the knee

* Anteromedial corner of the talus in the ankle

* Superomedial part of the femoral head

* Humeral capitulum

* Head of the second metatarsal bone

Clinically, they present with intermittent pain over the mid-foot, which may be accompanied by swelling and a small effusion in the joint. It typically resolves over the years, as the child grows up.

X-ray imaging, MRI, and radionuclide scanning with 99mTc-HDP are the imaging modalities used for diagnosis.

Treatment includes symptomatic treatment of pain. Special supportive shoes may also be considered.

Other options:

Option A: Osteochondritis of the lunate is known as Kienbock's disease.

Option B: Osteochondritis of the capitulum is known as Panner's disease.

Option D: Osteochondritis of the calcaneum is known as Sever's disease.

questions.text: 186. An elderly man has complained of shortness of breath for the past few months. He has a smoking history of a 40-pack-year. His physical examination reveals a barrel chest and diffuse wheeze with hyper-resonance on percussion. Which of the following pressure-volume curves will you observe in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of emphysema, which shows increased compliance as depicted by graph 1 in the image. 

Emphysema is a chronic obstructive pulmonary disease characterised by destruction of alveoli and lung air space enlargement. Clinical features include dyspnea on exertion, cough, with signs of hyperinflation such as a barrel-shaped chest and hyperresonance on percussion. The history of smoking is a major risk factor for COPD patients. 

Compliance is defined by the change in lung volume per unit change of pressure is increased in emphysema due to air trapping or hyperinflation, which is also seen in chest X-ray by flattening of the diaphragm.

Pearl PM0087: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

* Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance

* For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume

* Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation

* If the surface tension is more, compliance is less

* Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

* Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.

* Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.

* If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.

* Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

* Pulmonary emphysema

* Normal aging lung

questions.text:
187. In which of the following situations will you use a sanitizer?

* Before examining the patient

* After examining the patient

* After touching the patients surroundings

* Hands are visibly soiled
questions.solution:
You should use a sanitiser before and after examining the patient and after touching the patients' surroundings.

The hands should be washed with soap and water thoroughly in case they are visibly soiled.

Disinfectants like chlorhexidine and alexidine have a biguanide functional group. They are mostly used as oral disinfectants and hand products. They are bactericidal but not sporicidal. Mycobacteria are also resistant to these compounds.

188. A 50-year-old female patient known case of mitral stenosis came for a regular follow-up. On auscultation, she was found to have a soft first heart sound. The doctor ordered a transthoracic echocardiogram to assess flow rate and trans atrioventricular pressure. Which of the following findings are likely to be seen?

* Cardiac output is normal at rest and rises subnormally on exercise. 

* The left atrial pressure is elevated, resulting in increased pulmonary venous and pulmonary arterial pressure.

* Mitral valve orifice area is 2.3 cm².

* The left ventricle is enlarged in size to increase preload.

* Tricuspid valve regurgitation due to increased pulmonary arterial pressure
questions.solution:
The findings likely to be seen in this patient are 1, 2, and 5.

This 50-year-old female with a history of mitral stenosis, presenting with a soft first heart sound (S1) and findings on echocardiography, is most consistent with severe mitral stenosis. The presence of a soft S1 reflects advanced valve calcification and reduced mobility of the mitral leaflets.

Severe mitral stenosis is defined when the mitral valve orifice area is less than 1.5 cm² (very severe if <1.0 cm²). The normal valve orifice is about 4–6 cm².

Clinical Findings in Severe Mitral Stenosis

* Cardiac output is normal at rest in severe mitral stenosis and rises subnormally during exertion, emotional states, and tachycardia, leading to increased left atrial pressure, which can cause dyspnea and cough. (Statement 1)

* Cardiac output is decreased in very severe mitral stenosis, and it rises subnormally or even falls during exertion

* Pulmonary artery pressure increases due to increased left atrial pressure (Statement 2)

* Rise in pulmonary artery pressure causes- Right ventricle enlargement, tricuspid regurgitation, and pulmonary valvular stenosis. (Statement 5)

There is no change in left ventricular volume in mitral stenosis (Statement 4). Mitral valve area of 2.3 cm² does not indicate severe stenosis (rules out Statement 3).

Causes of mitral stenosis:

* Rheumatic heart disease - most common cause

* Congenital mitral valve stenosis

* Cor triatriatum

* Rheumatic arthritis

* Systemic lupus erythematosus

* Infective endocarditis with large vegetations

* Left atrial myxoma

189. A 3-year-old child was referred to the Ophthalmology department for evaluation of upper eyelid ptosis. Previous photographs suggest that it has been present from birth. The external eye measurements are given below. Which among the following surgeries is used to manage this case?

  Right eye Left eye
Palpebral fissure 4mm 4mm
Levator function Normal Poor
questions.solution:
Frontalis sling suspension is done for congenital ptosis with poor levator function.

Ptosis refers to the drooping of the upper eyelid such that it covers more than 2 mm of the superior cornea. It may be congenital or acquired.

Congenital ptosis may be classified as:

* Simple - isolated abnormality

* Complicated -associated with ocular motor anomalies, blepharophimosis syndrome, and Marcus Gunn ptosis.

The presence of congenital ptosis should be confirmed by photographs taken during childhood. It is usually bilateral and is due to defective development of the muscle.

Measurements to assess ptosis:

* Margin-reflex distance: The distance between the upper lid margin and the corneal reflection of a torch held by the examiner on which the patient fixates. It is normally 4–5 mm.

* Palpebral fissure height: The distance between the upper and lower lid margins. It is measured in the pupillary plane. Normally, it is 7–10 mm in males and 8–12 mm in females. Ptosis can be graded based on the difference between the height of the palpebral aperture in two eyes in unilateral cases and in bilateral cases, by the amount of cornea covered by the upper lid minus 2mm

* mild (up to 2 mm)

* moderate (2-3 mm)

* severe (4 mm or more)

* Levator function (upper lid excursion): It is measured by placing the thumb firmly against the patient’s brow with the gaze fixed downwards. The patient is then asked to look up as much as possible and the amount of excursion is measured with a ruler. It is graded as:

* Good:12–14 mm

* Fair: 5–11 mm

* Poor: 4 mm or less

When the levator function is poor (3 mm or less), the eyelid is suspended from the frontalis muscle using sutures, a fascia lata sling, or a silicone band. Infection of the suture bed is a complication of this surgery and the suture should be monitored.

Surgical treatment of various types of ptosis:

In patients with  good to moderate levator action:

Fasanella Servat < 2 mm Horner Syndrome
Levator Resection – Anterior approach Any Larger resection in ptosis
Levator resection – Conjunctival approach Any Moderate resection in ptosis
Levator resection with aponeurotic reinsertion Any Acquired ptosis


In patients with poor levator action:

Surgery     Amount of ptosis that can be treated Indications
Frontalis suspension – Fascia lata > 2 mm Congenital ptosis, especially Marcus Gunn Ptosis

questions.text:
190. Which of the following are representatives of interval scale data?

* Child-Pugh score

* Temperature in Kelvin

* Intelligence Quotient

* Temperature in Celsius 

* Blood groups
questions.solution:
Intelligence Quotient(3) and the temperature in Celsius(4)are measured on the Interval Scale.

Interval scale data can be placed in a meaningful order. Additionally, they have meaningful intervals between the items, usually measurable quantities. For example, the difference between 100° and 90° is the same as that between 50° and 40° on the Celsius temperature scale. But these scales do not have absolute zeroes, which makes ratios between the items meaningless.

Intelligence Quotient (IQ) is considered an interval scale because the difference between scores is meaningful and consistent across the scale. For example, the difference between an IQ of 110 and 100 reflects the same magnitude of difference in intelligence as the difference between 120 and 110. However, IQ does not have a true zero point. This absence of a true zero distinguishes it from ratio data. IQ is not ordinal because ordinal data only indicate rank or order, whereas IQ scores have equal, standardised intervals between values, making differences meaningful.

Data will always fall into one of the four scales- Nominal, Ordinal, Interval and Ratio scales. Nominal scale data can be divided into qualitative categories or groups. No order or ratio from the data is implied. An example includes types of blood groups(5). Other examples are groups like male/female, black/white and urban/suburban/rural.

Ordinal scale data holds meaning when it is placed in a particular order. But there is no information about the interval size. An example is the Child-Pugh score(1). Other examples are TNM staging of tumours and the Glasgow coma score. IQ is not ordinal because ordinal data only indicate rank or order, whereas IQ scores have equal, standardized intervals between values, making differences meaningful.

Ratio scale data have similar properties to interval scale data. In addition, they have an absolute zero and meaningful ratios exist. Most biomedical variables can be measured on a ratio scale, like blood pressure, heart rate and weight. Another example is the temperature scale in Kelvin(2).

Pearl PM2138: Scales of data measurement

Quantitative data can be discrete variables or continuous variables.

Can take any value usually in between limits or a range.

Data always forms one of four scales of measurement – nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scales (mnemonic: NOIR):

Ordinal Scale Data

Notes

No size interval is defined

Example: Temperature in Celsius. If temperature in A is 40 deg Celsius and that in B is 20 deg Celsius, then A is 20 deg Celsius hotter than B (taking difference)

For example, Celsius scale has no such thing as “no temperature”. So the value cannot be zero.

questions.text: 191. A young woman presents with itchy skin lesions on her wrists. On examination, purple, polygonal, plaques are seen on the wrist. The lesions have a thin white line on their surface. On examination of the oral cavity, the following finding is seen. Which of the following is seen on the microscopy?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the image showing thin white lines on the oral mucosa known as Wickham striae are suggestive of lichen planus. Microscopy will show the presence of colloid bodies (Civatte bodies).

Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membrane. Microscopy will show acanthosis of the epidermis, irregular thickening of the granular layer, and compact hyperkeratosis. Degenerating basal epidermal cells are transformed into colloid bodies. The rete ridges may have the sawtooth appearance, and focal separation from the dermis may lead to Max-Joseph spaces. In active LP, a band‐like infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes is seen near the dermo-epidermal junction.



Patients present with pruritic, purple, polygonal, papules. The lesions have thin, white lines on their surface known as Wickham striae. They are commonly seen on the volar aspect of the wrists, the lumbar region, and around the ankles.

Mucosal involvement is also seen. The commonest mucosal sites are buccal mucosa and tongue, rarely it can also be found on the anus and genitalia. 

Nail involvement can be seen as thinning of the nail plate, leading to an exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions. The nails can also be destroyed leading to anonychia. Involvement of the nail bed may give rise to longitudinal melanonychia, hyperpigmentation, subungual hyperkeratosis, or onycholysis.

Other options:

Option A - Burrow of mite is seen in scabies. The patients will have skin lesions that are very itchy and worse at night. The family members will also have similar complaints. It is commonly present in the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, the elbows, the axillae, the buttocks and genitalia, and women's breasts.



Option B - Munro microabscess is the accumulation of neutrophils in the stratum corneum. The lesions present as red scaly plaques, which are well demarcated from the surrounding normal skin. They might have a circle of clear zone around it, which is known as the Woronoff ring.



Option C - Tear-shaped microconidia are seen in tinea corporis, which is commonly caused due to Trichophyton rubrum. The lesions are circular, usually sharply marginated with a raised edge. There might be a similar history in the close contacts.



Pearl PM1995: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

questions.text: 192. A 30-year-old woman presents with persistent vaginal bleeding 8 months postpartum. Serum β-hCG is low but persistent. Ultrasound shows a myometrial mass with minimal vascularity. Endometrial biopsy reveals intermediate trophoblastic cells without syncytiotrophoblasts, consistent with Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor (PSTT). She is hemodynamically stable. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Hysterectomy is the treatment of choice for Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor (PSTT), as this tumor is relatively resistant to chemotherapy.

Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor (PSTT) is a rare subtype of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) that arises from intermediate trophoblasts at the placental implantation site. Unlike choriocarcinoma (which arises from syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts), PSTT lacks syncytiotrophoblastic elements. This unique origin explains both its clinical presentation and its resistance to chemotherapy.

It typically presents months to years after a term pregnancy, abortion, or molar pregnancy. Notably, cases presenting many years after the index pregnancy often carry a worse prognosis.

The hallmark presentation is persistent or irregular vaginal bleeding long after pregnancy. Because PSTT secretes low levels of β-hCG (due to the absence of syncytiotrophoblasts), the elevation is mild but persistent, unlike the very high levels seen in choriocarcinoma. Patients may also have uterine enlargement, amenorrhea, or abdominal pain. Rarely, they present with metastasis (lungs, brain, liver).

Diagnosis:

* Ultrasound: Shows a uterine mass infiltrating the myometrium, with minimal vascularity (contrasting with the highly vascular choriocarcinoma).

* Doppler: Confirms low vascular flow.

* Serum β-hCG: Persistently low or plateauing.

* Histopathology: Shows proliferation of intermediate trophoblasts with hyaline-like material, absence of villi, minimal syncytiotrophoblasts, and high mitotic index.

* Immunohistochemistry: Positive for human placental lactogen (hPL), negative/weak for hCG.

Chemotherapy (usually multi-agent regimens such as EMA-EP) is reserved for metastatic or recurrent disease, but response rates are lower compared to choriocarcinoma.

Other options:

Option A. Multi-agent chemotherapy with EMA-CO (etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin-D, cyclophosphamide, vincristine) is the standard regimen for high-risk GTN such as choriocarcinoma or invasive mole. 

Option B. Single-agent chemotherapy with methotrexate is the first-line therapy for low-risk GTN (e.g., non-metastatic choriocarcinoma, molar pregnancy). In PSTT, methotrexate is ineffective due to the tumor’s chemoresistance.

Option D. Repeat suction and curettage is appropriate in a molar pregnancy or retained products of conception. PSTT is a solid tumor infiltrating the myometrium, not just confined to the endometrial cavity. Curettage would not remove the disease and may even risk bleeding or incomplete clearance.

questions.text:
193. A preterm neonate develops respiratory distress and a continuous murmur at the left infraclavicular area. The echocardiogram shows left-to-right shunting at the ductal level. Which of the following best explains the clinical significance of PDA in this setting?

 PDA- Patent ductus arteriosus

choices.text: It always closes spontaneously by 2 weeks of age
Reduces the risk of necrotising enterocolitis

questions.solution:
Patent ductus arteriosus(PDA) causes pulmonary overcirculation & systemic hypoperfusion. 

In patent ductus arteriosus, there is significant left-to-right shunting where blood flows from the aorta to the pulmonary artery. Hence, there is pulmonary overcirculation leading to pulmonary edema, respiratory distress. Blood is stolen from the systemic circulation, leading to systemic hypoperfusion. This leads to complications such as necrotising enterocolitis, renal ischemia.

Ductus arteriosus is a fetal vessel connecting the pulmonary artery and the descending aorta, bypassing the lungs. Its persistence beyond 2-3 weeks is called PDA. It is more common in premature infants and also seen in high-altitude infants.

Associated syndromes are congenital rubella syndrome and smooth muscle dysfunction syndrome (ACTA2 mutation). Irrespective of age, patients with a PDA require either catheter or surgical closure. In patients with a small PDA, the rationale for closure is prevention of bacterial endarteritis.

Other options: 

Option A. In premature infants, the smooth muscle in the wall of the preterm ductus is less responsive to high PO2 and therefore less likely to constrict after birth. Therefore, a PDA is especially symptomatic, leading to hemodynamic derangements.

Option C. PDA closing spontaneously is true only for most term infants, not for preterm infants, where the wall is less responsive to PO2. 

Option D. PDA increases the risk of necrotising enterocolitis because of systemic hypoperfusion.

196. Match the following types of zoonoses with their diseases:

  Category of zoonoses Diseases
1. Cyclo-zoonoses a. Plague
2. Meta-zoonoses b. Taeniasis
3. Amphixenosis c. Brucellosis
4. Direct zoonoses d. Salmonellosis
questions.solution:
The correct match is 

  Category of zoonoses Diseases
1. Cyclo-zoonoses b. Taeniasis
2. Meta-zoonoses a. Plague
3. Amphixenosis d. Salmonellosis
4. Direct zoonoses c. Brucellosis


 

Cyclozoonoses are zoonoses that require two or more vertebrate hosts to complete their life cycle but do not involve any invertebrate vector. The classic example is Taeniasis, caused by Taenia solium or T. saginata, where humans are the definitive hosts and pigs/cattle are the intermediate hosts.

Metazoonoses involve transmission that requires both vertebrate and invertebrate hosts, with the pathogen undergoing development or multiplication in the invertebrate vector. Plague, caused by Yersinia pestis, is transmitted via flea bites from infected rodents. Other examples include:

* Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) – spread by ticks, with monkeys as vertebrate reservoirs.

* Japanese Encephalitis – spread by Culex mosquitoes, with pigs and birds as amplifying hosts.

* Leishmaniasis – transmitted via sandflies from animal reservoirs.

* Schistosomiasis (Schistosoma spp.) – involves snails as intermediate hosts (invertebrates) and humans/mammals as definitive hosts. 

Amphixenoses are zoonotic diseases that can be transmitted in both directions — from animals to humans and vice versa.

* Salmonellosis – poultry, reptiles, and other animals can transmit Salmonella spp. to humans; human carriers can also spread the bacteria.

* Dermatophytosis (Ringworm) – spreads from infected pets or livestock to humans, and vice versa.

Direct zoonoses are those transmitted directly from infected vertebrate animals to humans through contact, inhalation, or ingestion — without vectors.

* Brucellosis – via contact with infected animal products or unpasteurized dairy.

* Rabies – through bites or saliva of infected animals.

* Anthrax – contact with spores from infected carcasses or hides.

* Zoonotic Tuberculosis (Mycobacterium bovis) – from unpasteurized milk.

questions.text: 197. A 27-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus develops sudden tremors, profuse sweating, and confusion while on a hiking trip. She is disoriented and cannot follow instructions. A fingerstick test shows her blood glucose level to be 31 mg/dL. Her symptoms resolve after her friend administers an intramuscular injection. What is the most likely mechanism of action of the medication given?
questions.solution:
The most likely mechanism of action of the drug given to the patient is activation of adenylyl cyclase.

The clinical scenario is suggestive of a patient suffering from an acute episode of hypoglycemia, which resolved after receiving an intramuscular injection. Glucagon was most likely administered to this patient, which acts via the activation of adenylyl cyclase.

Glucagon binds to its receptor, activating adenylyl cyclase and increasing cAMP levels. This triggers protein kinase A, which phosphorylates enzymes like glycogen phosphorylase and glycogen synthase. Phosphorylation activates glycogen phosphorylase and inhibits glycogen synthase, shifting the liver from storing glucose to producing it. As a result, glucagon helps raise blood glucose levels by promoting gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, counteracting insulin-induced hypoglycemia.

The action pathway of glucagon is shown in the illustrated image below:



Other Options:

Option A: Glucose-6-phosphatase releases glucose from glucose-6-phosphate. Inhibiting this enzyme reduces the release of glucose from cells, which would lower rather than raise the patient’s blood glucose levels.

Option B: Glucokinase catalyses the first step of glycolysis, leading to increased glucose utilisation and lowering of blood glucose levels. Activation of this enzyme occurs in glucose excess, when insulin is the predominant hormone.

Option C: Glucagon stimulates, not inhibits, glycogen phosphorylase, which is responsible for the rate-limiting step in glycogenolysis. Blocking this enzyme would reduce glycogen breakdown, leading to a decrease in blood glucose levels rather than an increase.

198. A 40-year-old female had undergone a pap smear test whose reports show dysplastic cells in the lower 1/3rd of the cervix. What would be the next step of management in the given scenario?

HPV- Human Papilloma Virus

LLETZ- Large loop excision of the transformation zone
questions.solution:
Dysplastic changes in the lower 1/3rd of cervical tissue are graded as cervical intraepithelial neoplasia I (CIN I).

These mild dysplastic changes are usually after HPV infection, therefore the next step is HPV testing. If that is due to an infection, it is treated and cytology follow-up is done.

Treatment for Dysplasia and CIN: 

1. Mild dysplasia/ LSIL/CIN-1: Is usually due to infection, therefore it is treated and cytology is followed up every 3-6 months. Colposcopy is indicated in:

* Persistent CIN-I over a year

* Poor compliance

* LSIL progressing to HSIL in follow-up

2. Moderate-severe dysplasia/CIN-II- CIN-III: Treatment options are:

* Local destructive methods: Cryosurgery, fulguration/ electrocoagulation, and laser ablation.

* Excision of abnormal tissue: Cold-knife conization, laser conization, LLETZ (Large loop excision of the transformation zone), LEEP (Loop electrosurgical excision procedure), and NETZ (Needle excision of the transformation zone).

* Surgery: Conization, hysterectomy.

questions.text: 199. While recording evidence in the court of law, the lawyer who had called the witness conducts an examination on the witness. He does this to clarify certain doubts and details raised in the cross-examination. What is this procedure called?
questions.solution:
The above procedure is called the re-direct examination.

Re-direct examination is the procedure done by the lawyer who summoned the witness to correct any mistake or clarify, or add any details to the statements of the witness made during the cross-examination.

The witness is not allowed to provide any new matter at this stage. Leading questions are not allowed in re-direct examination.

The sequence of examination in the recording of evidence is as follows -

Sequence of Examination Objective

Examination-in-chief/direct examination (options A and B) by the party that summoned the witness 

To elicit the facts of the case from the witness.

Leading questions are not allowed.

Cross-examination by the defense lawyer

To elicit facts favorable to their case and test the reliability of the witness.

Leading questions are allowed.

Re- direct examination by the party that summoned the witness

 To resolve doubts that formed during cross-examination and re-emphasize the party's perspective.


The opponent's lawyer will be allowed to do a re-cross examination (option D) on any new point raised in the re-direct examination.

questions.text:
200. Match the following tocolytics with their associated side effects:

 Tocolytics
  Major Side Effects
 1. Nifedipine

a. Hyperglycemia
 2. Indomethacin

b. Hypotension
3. Ritodrine

c. Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
4. Atosiban

d. Headache and nausea
questions.solution:
The correct match is 

   Tocolytics Major Side Effects
   1. Nifedipine b. Hypotension
   2. Indomethacin c. Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
   3. Ritodrine a. Hyperglycemia
   4. Atosiban d. Headache and nausea


 

Nifedipine acts by blocking L-type calcium channels in smooth muscle, thereby reducing calcium influx into myometrial cells. This leads to relaxation of the uterus and effective inhibition of contractions. It is considered a first-line tocolytic, especially before 32–34 weeks of gestation, because of its efficacy and safety profile. The major maternal side effect is hypotension, due to systemic vasodilation. Other adverse effects include flushing, tachycardia, dizziness, and headache, but it is generally well-tolerated with minimal fetal risks.

Indomethacin works by inhibiting cyclooxygenase (COX), leading to reduced prostaglandin synthesis, which is a key mediator of uterine contractions. It is a very effective tocolytic, particularly in pregnancies <32 weeks. However, beyond this gestational age, it carries significant fetal risks, most notably premature closure of the ductus arteriosus and oligohydramnios (due to reduced fetal renal perfusion). Maternal side effects include gastritis and platelet dysfunction. Hence, its use is restricted to early preterm labor. It is contraindicated in cases of hepatic disease, active peptic ulcer, and coagulation disorders.

Ritodrine is a β2-receptor agonist that stimulates adenylate cyclase, increasing intracellular cAMP, which in turn relaxes myometrial smooth muscle.  The hallmark side effect is maternal hyperglycemia, as it promotes glycogenolysis and lipolysis. Other complications include tachycardia, hypokalemia, pulmonary edema, arrhythmias, and tremors. Neonates exposed in utero may develop tachycardia or hypoglycemia. 

Atosiban is a selective oxytocin receptor antagonist that prevents oxytocin binding, thereby reducing calcium-mediated uterine contractions. The drug is well-tolerated, with the most common side effects being headache, nausea, and dizziness. Unlike nifedipine or ritodrine, atosiban has minimal cardiovascular effects, making it particularly useful in patients with underlying heart disease.
